McFall-Johnsen)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608ad0ec34af8d0018599e6f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn75@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-25-735_d5e26df3a945a9ae.webp","https://i.insider.com/608af90b34af8d0018599f7b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn53@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-24-100_2b91d4b2e46644b9.webp","https://i.insider.com/606b2c35856cd700198a325d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn46@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-25-688_483dc8b32e096174.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f219eca7924a12c8c4441ef?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn62@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-25-105_731a122b9f3e0bf6.webp","https://i.insider.com/6064ac0ddaf0f10018f99422?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn100@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-21-990_b69585207ed42bc6.webp","https://i.insider.com/608ad3b435c46f0018c0b3e2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn84@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-887_ff8b05130a3c34fe.webp","https://i.insider.com/608ad48735c46f0018c0b3ec?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn58@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-29-159_93afdb3291da427f.webp","https://i.insider.com/607d633944f4540019207601?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn37@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-25-035_b2c62c882f60f4f7.webp","https://i.insider.com/607d7a2b44f4540019207624?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn48@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-24-783_2fd3ac3cce7ab3bd.webp","https://i.insider.com/608197c2354dde0018c06a30?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn60@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-24-237_056926bc4a9a7e43.webp","https://i.insider.com/608675f13f0560001881bf33?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn79@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-21-887_2f1b463bca94ead4.webp","https://i.insider.com/608ae9b734af8d0018599f2a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-21-341_0c88d2cb4e527a22.webp","https://i.insider.com/608992ee3f0560001881c8ef?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn35@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-21-518_e20279e636f6a474.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c659f34af8d001859a5e6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn8@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-22-376_d0df267f67f7632d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=j02kGrUND_0:ZezE68QiXi4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn76@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-21-216_aa348107f587b977.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=j02kGrUND_0:ZezE68QiXi4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn29@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-24-007_a287aacededacba3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=j02kGrUND_0:ZezE68QiXi4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn27@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-21-371_fb049e055cd6a177.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/j02kGrUND_0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn81@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-25-996_468c60a74bfb5c9c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324317},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"Polar bear and grizzly bear hybrids, known as 'pizzly bears,' could become more common because of the climate crisis","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/pizzly-bears-polar-grizzly-hybrid-spread-due-to-climate-crisis-2021-4","description":"<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608cef8a34af8d001859a692?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pizzly bear polar grizzly hybrid animal\" height=\"3400\" width=\"4533\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   A pizzly bear, or grolar bear, bred in captivity at a zoo in Germany. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">Philippe Clement/Arterra/Universal Images Group via Getty Images</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\"> \n <li>When polar bears and grizzly bears mate, the hybrid is called a pizzly bear, or a grolar bear.</li> \n <li>Pizzlies are becoming more common in the Arctic and the climate crisis is likely playing a role.</li> \n <li>As grizzly bears move further north with warmer temperatures, they're more likely to meet polar bears.</li> \n <li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider's business page</a>.</li> \n</ul>\n<p>Pizzly bears, sometimes called grolar bears, are a bear hybrid that could become more common in the Arctic as a result of the climate crisis.</p>\n<p>The pizzly bear is the result of polar bears and grizzly bears breeding, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i0D0SC-32Zs\">according to Larisa DeSantis</a>, a biology professor at Vanderbilt University.</p>\n<p>\"We've known about pizzlies for quite some time, but their occurrence may be more common with ongoing Arctic warming,\" DeSantis said.</p>\n<p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/e-commerce-hinders-emissions-goals-ups-fedex-amazon-sustainability-2021-4\" data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\">Amazon, FedEx, and UPS have grand goals to slash emissions. Cashing in on the pandemic e-commerce boom suddenly made them much harder to reach.</a></em></p>\n<p>A pizzly was first discovered in the wild in 2006, when a hunter in Canada's far north killed a bear with white fur and brown patches as well as the humped back and long claws characteristic of a grizzly bear. DNA testing confirmed the bear was a hybrid, <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/a48d3967d653e5a081e071ad73c7526f\">The Associated Press</a> reported at the time.</p>\n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ceff4f22c6b00185db1c5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pizzly bear polar grizzly hybrid\" height=\"2552\" width=\"3403\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   Pizzly bear and grolar bear are both unofficial terms for the animal. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">Philippe Clement/Arterra/Universal Images Group via Getty Images</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<p>Since then, sightings of pizzlies in the wild have become more common. A <a href=\"https://journalhosting.ucalgary.ca/index.php/arctic/article/view/67681\">2017 study</a> published in the journal Arctic documented eight pizzlies who were the offspring of one female polar bear that had mated with two separate grizzly bears.</p>\n<p>According to DeSantis, grizzly bears are moving further north as temperatures rise. Meanwhile, \"polar bears are increasingly having to search for other food sources, when hunting seals from sea ice become untenable,\" she said.</p>\n<p>Polar bears typically rely on sea ice to hunt for seals, which make up the vast majority of their diet. A <a href=\"https://science.sciencemag.org/content/359/6375/568\">2018 study</a> published in Science found as sea ice continues to decline, \"polar bears are likely to experience increasingly stressful conditions and higher mortality rates.\" And arctic sea ice is declining rapidly, as the Arctic experiences higher rates of warming than the rest of the globe, according to the <a href=\"https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-minimum-arctic-sea-ice-extent\">National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration</a>.</p>\n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608cf04f34af8d001859a696?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pizzly bear grolar polar grizzly hybrid animal\" height=\"3315\" width=\"4420\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   A pizzly bear, pictured here in captivity, was first discovered in the wild in 2006. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">Philippe Clement/Arterra/Universal Images Group via Getty Images</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<p>DeSantis said polar bears and grizzly bears have been observed near whale carcasses, prompting them to \"engage in opportunistic mating.\" Since polar bears and grizzlies only diverged about 500,000 to 600,000 years ago, she said, their offspring are able to produce offspring as well.</p>\n<p>But it will take time and additional research to know how well suited these hybrids are to survival.</p>\n<p>\"Most of the time, hybrids are not more vigorous than either of the two species,\" DeSantis said, adding that individual species generally have adaptations best suited for their habitat. But she said there have been some instances where hybrids are more vigorous, \"particularly if that environment is deviating from what it once was.\"</p>\n<p><em>Have a news tip? Contact this reporter at </em><a href=\"mailto:kvlamis@insider.com?inline-read-more\"><em>kvlamis@insider.com</em></a><em>.</em></p>\n<div class=\"read-original\">\n Read the original article on \n <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pizzly-bears-polar-grizzly-hybrid-spread-due-to-climate-crisis-2021-4\">Business Insider</a>\n</div>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/OrkVFbCwkX8\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 01 May 2021 06:26:52 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608cef8234af8d001859a691?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"33d441035ad32eb9e3455e20e002abea","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn2@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-21-036_68dc7be45bf61523.webp","destWidth":4387,"destHeight":3290,"sourceBytes":1220050,"destBytes":1220050,"author":"kvlamis@insider.com (Kelsey Vlamis)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608cef8a34af8d001859a692?format=jpeg":null,"https://i.insider.com/608ceff4f22c6b00185db1c5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn83@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-22-337_e146fa16a794cc65.webp","https://i.insider.com/608cf04f34af8d001859a696?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn1@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-24-140_81fb5ac9e928b156.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn27@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-26-055_311e3b2cbb99b0cd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn48@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-23-519_280e60f0b3f297d8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OrkVFbCwkX8:KhvvdBMRQtY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn30@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-25-640_b0b094116ec5ef40.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/OrkVFbCwkX8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn15@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-22-013_31f61d472bafea60.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324339},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"How to use spell check in Microsoft Word to eliminate typos and grammatical errors","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/spell-check-in-word","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608b836b34af8d001859a0c7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"word document\" height=\"2006\" width=\"4012\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Spell check in Word is a useful built-in tool to proof your writing, it and can be adjusted in several ways.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Canberk Sezer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li aria-level=\"1\">You can spell check in Microsoft Word by using its built-in spelling and grammar checker. </li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">If enabled, it will automatically underline spelling and grammatical errors.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">You can also open the Spelling &#38; Grammar dialog box to manually check all of the spelling and grammar issues in a document at once.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">The latest version of Microsoft 365 adds a new Editor pane to Word for enhanced spelling and grammar checking. </li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\"><strong>Visit Insider&#39;s Tech Reference library for more stories</strong></a><strong>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>Microsoft Word&#39;s ability to check spelling and grammar can be a professional lifesaver, informing you about embarrassing errors before you share the document with others.</p><p>Word can perform in-line spell checks automatically, but if you prefer to disable the feature or want a more comprehensive view, it&#39;s possible to check spelling and grammar manually across a document as well. </p><aside class=\"breakout-box headline-regular\"><h2><strong>How to use spell check in Word</strong></h2><p>If automatic spell checking is turned on - which it should be by default - it&#39;s easy to accept and reject misspelled words and see potential grammar problems. The steps are essentially the same on Windows and the Mac.<br><br></p><ol><li aria-level=\"1\">As you work, you should see a red squiggly line appear under misspelled words in your document. Phrases with potential grammar issues appear with a double-underline. </li><li aria-level=\"1\">To see suggested replacements, right-click the underlined word in Windows or control-click the word on the Mac.</li><li aria-level=\"1\">Choose the option you prefer from the dropdown menu. If the word doesn&#39;t really need correction, you can also choose to &#34;Add to Dictionary&#34; or ignore the word.<br><br><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608b843235c46f0018c0b62d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to spell check in Microsoft Word 1\" height=\"742\" width=\"1319\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Right-click (Windows) or control-click (Mac) words to see suggested corrections.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></li></ol><p> </p></aside><aside class=\"breakout-box headline-regular\"><h2><strong>How to turn automatic spell check on and off in Word for Windows</strong></h2><p>If you want to disable automatic spelling and grammar checking (or turn it back on after it&#39;s been turned off) you can do that in Word Options. You can also control spelling and grammar separately, so you can check spelling automatically but defer automatic grammar checks.  <br><br></p><ol><li aria-level=\"1\">Click the &#34;File&#34; tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen, then click &#34;Options.&#34;</li><li aria-level=\"1\">In the navigation pane, click &#34;Proofing.&#34;</li><li aria-level=\"1\">Turn spell check on or off with the option called &#34;Check spelling as you type.&#34; You can also choose to turn grammar checking on or off with &#34;Mark grammar errors as you type.&#34;</li><li aria-level=\"1\">When you&#39;re done, click &#34;OK.&#34;<br> <figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608b859435c46f0018c0b62f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to spell check in Microsoft Word 2\" height=\"1379\" width=\"2452\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can enable or disable automatic spell check in Word Options.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></li></ol></aside><aside class=\"breakout-box headline-regular\"><h2><strong>How to turn automatic spell check on and off in Word for Mac</strong></h2><p>You can turn automatic spelling and grammar checks on and off in Word&#39;s preferences. You can control both settings separately, so you can check spelling automatically but defer automatic grammar checks.<br><br></p><ol><li aria-level=\"1\">In the Word menu, click &#34;Preferences.&#34;</li><li aria-level=\"1\">In the Word Preferences dialog box, click &#34;Spelling &#38; Grammar.&#34;</li><li aria-level=\"1\">In the Spelling section, turn &#34;Check spelling as you type&#34; on or off. In the Grammar section, do the same for &#34;Check grammar as you type.&#34;<br> <figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608b874735c46f0018c0b631?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How_to_spell_check_in_Microsoft_Word 3\" height=\"2190\" width=\"2321\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can choose whether to let Word automatically flag spelling errors in Preferences.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><br> </li></ol></aside><aside class=\"breakout-box headline-regular\"><h2><strong>How to manually check spelling and grammar in Word</strong></h2><p>There may be times when you want to check spelling and grammar manually, such as if you&#39;ve turned off automatic spell check or if you have a long document and want to make sure you don&#39;t miss any of the spelling or grammar issues that Word flagged.</p><p>The process is the same on both Windows and the Mac. <br><br></p><ol><li aria-level=\"1\">Click the &#34;Review&#34; tab in the ribbon at the top of the screen. </li><li aria-level=\"1\">In the ribbon, click &#34;Spelling &#38; Grammar.&#34;</li><li aria-level=\"1\">If there are any spelling or grammar issues, the Spelling and Grammar dialog box will appear. You&#39;ll see a list of suggestions for each potential error. You can choose how you&#39;d like to respond to each entry - you can ignore the word, change it to one of the suggestions, or add it to Word&#39;s spell check dictionary.<br> <figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608b886134af8d001859a0cd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How_to_spell_check_in_Microsoft_Word 4\" height=\"2240\" width=\"2379\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can check all the spelling and grammar issues in a document at once using the Spelling &#38; Grammar button in the Review ribbon.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></li></ol></aside><h2>How to check spelling and grammar in Word with the Editor pane</h2><p>If you are using Microsoft 365, you may see a different way to manually check for spelling and grammar. Instead of the &#34;Spelling &#38; Grammar&#34; button in the Review ribbon, there&#39;s a new &#34;Editor&#34; button. This opens the Editor pane on the right side of the screen. You will see a summary at the top of the screen, so you know how many suggested changes remain, along with details for spelling and grammar below. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608b894f35c46f0018c0b634?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to spell check in Microsoft Word 5\" height=\"1184\" width=\"2105\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The new Editor pane offers more detailed spelling and grammar controls.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Click &#34;Spelling&#34; and you&#39;ll see the word in the context of the surrounding text with suggested changes. The editor also provides brief definitions for these suggestions to make it easier to choose the best option. You can also choose other traditional options like &#34;Ignore&#34; or &#34;Add to dictionary.&#34;</p><bi-shortcode id=\"related-article-module-end-of-article\" class=\"mceNonEditable\"><a 2021 20:23:57 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608b835735c46f0018c0b62c?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"263a369fa7d6ba5ad778beeffbb92d63","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn51@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-20-980_cd7c773b8a5cf3ce.webp","destWidth":3573,"destHeight":2679,"sourceBytes":143424,"destBytes":143424,"author":"insider@insider.com (Dave Johnson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608b836b34af8d001859a0c7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn27@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-26-221_99143c347e14d89a.webp","https://i.insider.com/608b843235c46f0018c0b62d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn39@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-21-915_b7558ccfcac8a40b.webp","https://i.insider.com/608b859435c46f0018c0b62f?format=jpeg":null,"https://i.insider.com/608b874735c46f0018c0b631?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn13@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-24-315_ca8a992cea9eee28.webp","https://i.insider.com/608b886134af8d001859a0cd?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn35@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-22-696_6c35852618ee8327.webp","https://i.insider.com/608b894f35c46f0018c0b634?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn48@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-26-118_aa34ad963721b9d1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=XbGc6AaYMdw:hQu02lhRT3Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn12@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-24-455_1845f910acbcb351.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=XbGc6AaYMdw:hQu02lhRT3Q:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn73@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-25-149_9ae0bdeef6de93ab.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=XbGc6AaYMdw:hQu02lhRT3Q:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn23@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-24-581_2bab2a5e97a820a0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/XbGc6AaYMdw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn44@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-21-840_934b2b8c848fbf5f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324308},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"How 'America's Mayor' Rudy Giuliani could face criminal charges from the office he once led","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-rudy-giuliani-landed-in-doj-crosshairs-what-to-know-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/605738c3cad7d300183f835b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages Rudy Giuliani\" height=\"2441\" width=\"4882\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Rudolph Giuliani, attorney for President Donald Trump, conducts a news conference at the Republican National Committee on lawsuits regarding the outcome of the 2020 presidential election on Thursday, November 19, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/rudolph-giuliani-attorney-for-president-donald-trump-news-photo/1229782596?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">Tom Williams/CQ-Roll Call, Inc via Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Trumpworld was rocked by scandal when the feds raided Rudy Giuliani&#39;s home and office.</li>\n<li>The raids were part of a longrunning investigation into whether Giuliani broke foreign lobbying laws.</li>\n<li>Here&#39;s everything you need to know about the inquiry.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The political sphere flew into a frenzy this week amid news that the FBI raided the property of yet another lawyer working for former President Donald Trump.</p><p>The feds on Wednesday executed search warrants on Rudy Giuliani&#39;s home and office and seized his electronic devices. Agents also seized a computer belonging to his personal assistant, Jo Ann Zafonte, served Zafonte with a grand jury subpoena, and raided the Washington, DC, home of Giuliani&#39;s associate Victoria Toensing.</p><p>It was the most significant development to date in an ongoing Justice Department investigation into whether Giuliani broke foreign lobbying laws while working as Trump&#39;s lawyer.</p><p>Giuliani has not been charged with a crime, and he has denied any wrongdoing. His lawyer, Robert Costello, called the FBI&#39;s raids &#34;legal thuggery&#34; and said in a <a href=\"https://rudygiulianics.com/2021/04/28/statement-by-robert-j-costello-on-april-28-2021/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">statement</a> that they reflected a &#34;corrupt double standard&#34; at the Justice Department.</p><p>Here&#39;s everything you need to know about Trumpworld&#39;s latest scandal:</p><h3>Who&#39;s investigating Giuliani?</h3><p>The US attorney&#39;s office for the Southern District of New York - sometimes called the Sovereign District of New York because of its <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/with-bannon-arrest-sovereign-district-sends-another-salvo/2020/08/21/c9b51f16-e36c-11ea-82d8-5e55d47e90ca_story.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">independent reputation</a> - is leading the investigation. It&#39;s an ironic twist for Giuliani, who served as <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/1985/06/09/magazine/high-profile-prosecutor.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">head of the SDNY</a> from 1983 to 1989.</p><h3>How did Giuliani land in the SDNY&#39;s crosshairs?</h3><p>Federal prosecutors began scrutinizing the former New York mayor as part of a broader investigation into two of his Soviet-born business associates, Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman. The two men were arrested in October 2019 on suspicion of trying to funnel foreign money into a pro-Trump super PAC and other entities to gain leverage in US political circles. Prosecutors also alleged that Parnas and Fruman tried to influence US-Ukraine relations.</p><p>The Washington Post <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/two-business-associates-of-trumps-personal-lawyer-giuliani-have-been-arrested-and-are-in-custody/2019/10/10/9f9c101a-eb63-11e9-9306-47cb0324fd44_story.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reported</a> that the men had been working with Giuliani since late 2018 to find damaging information about the Bidens ahead of the 2020 election. John Dowd, an attorney representing Parnas and Fruman, told Congress in a statement shortly before their arrest that they had helped Giuliani in his work for Trump.</p><h3>What are prosecutors investigating?</h3><p>The full scope of the criminal inquiry is unclear, but its central thread appears to be focused on Giuliani&#39;s longrunning effort to dig up dirt on the Bidens. Specifically, prosecutors are examining if he was working solely in his capacity as Trump&#39;s lawyer, or if he was also working on behalf of foreign interests who believed they would benefit from Trump&#39;s reelection.</p><p>Investigators are said to be particularly focused on Giuliani&#39;s role in the abrupt removal of Marie Yovanovitch, the US&#39;s former ambassador to Ukraine. Yovanovitch&#39;s ouster was part of a broader effort by Trump and Giuliani to strongam Ukraine into launching political investigations targeting the Bidens ahead of the 2020 election.</p><p>Yovanovitch <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-impeachment-hearings-yovanovitch-testimony-updates-2019-11\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">testified to Congress</a> that as part of that effort, Giuliani collaborated with corrupt Ukrainian interests on a smear campaign against her that was based on &#34;false claims by people with clearly questionable motives.&#34;</p><p>Giuliani confirmed his role in Yovanovitch&#39;s removal, telling The New Yorker that he needed her <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rudy-giuliani-i-needed-yovanovitch-out-of-the-way-2019-12\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"42c6d9023c4ee91f74140224f11b3867\">&#34;out of the way&#34;</a> because &#34;she was going to make the investigations difficult for everybody.&#34;</p><p>Now, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/29/nyregion/giuliani-yovanovitch-search-warrant-ukraine.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">prosecutors are looking at</a> whether Giuliani targeted Yovanovitch at <a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/recording-appears-capture-trump-private-dinner-ukraine-ambassador/story?id=68506437\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Trump&#39;s direction</a>, or if he also did so at the behest of Ukrainian officials who wanted Yovanovitch ousted for their own reasons.</p><h3>What could Giuliani be charged with?</h3><p>If Giuliani was working on behalf of foreign interests, it could violate a law known as the Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA).</p><p>Put simply, FARA requires that American citizens notify the Justice Department of any contacts they have with foreign governments or officials, and if they interact with the US government or media at the direction of those officials.</p><p>In its modern context, &#34;the core purpose of FARA is to put US government officials and the American people on notice when a foreign government or other foreign interest is behind efforts to influence their opinions or actions, so that they can appropriately consider and weigh information or content in light of that underlying foreign interest,&#34; David Laufman, a partner at Wiggin and Dana and former top Justice Department official who oversaw FARA enforcement, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fara-foreign-agents-registration-act-doj-enforcement-rudy-giuliani-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">told Insider&#39;s Dave Levinthal and Ryan Barber.</a></p><h3>Where does the investigation currently stand?</h3><p>The longrunning inquiry entered an aggressive new phase with this week&#39;s FBI raids.</p><p>Executing a search warrant on a lawyer is an extraordinary step that requires high-level approval and a sign-off from a federal magistrate judge. To secure such a warrant, prosecutors would have had to prove they had reason to believe Giuliani&#39;s home and office contained evidence of a crime.</p><p>According to The Times, investigators had been trying to secure a warrant against Giuliani for months, but Trump appointees at the Justice Department quashed their efforts. The probe <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/federal-criminal-investigation-into-rudy-giuliani-resumes-ap-2021-3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"986615219eb32a20e3d7891ccc3ab36a\">resumed in earnest last month</a>, and the department lifted its objection to the warrant after Merrick Garland was confirmed as attorney general.</p><h3>What&#39;s the next shoe to drop?</h3><p>It&#39;s tough to say.</p><p>Giuliani has been in Trump&#39;s orbit for years, and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fbi-warned-giuliani-he-was-target-russian-disinformation-campaign-report-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the FBI warned him</a> as early as 2019 that the Russian government was using him as a tool to spread disinformation about Ukraine and the Biden family before the election. Despite the warning, Giuliani forged ahead with a trip to Kyiv in December 2019 where he met with Andriy Derkach, a Ukrainian official and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/treasury-sanction-ukraine-andrii-derkach-russia-trump-biden-dirt-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">active Russian agent</a>, as part of his mission to find dirt on the Bidens.</p><p>Giuliani was a fixture on conservative airwaves in the months leading up to the election, where he repeatedly amplified conspiracy theories about the Bidens and Ukraine. He also pushed the lie that Ukraine and not Russia interfered in the 2016 election, a talking point that can be traced back to Russian President Vladimir Putin.</p><p>Last October, he was instrumental in placing a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-york-post-hunter-joe-biden-giuliani-red-flags-disinformation-2020-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">highly controversial New York Post story</a> that purported to detail the Bidens&#39; corrupt ties to Ukraine based on a laptop the tabloid said belonged to Hunter Biden. Shortly after, NBC News reported that the FBI was investigating if the emails contained in the story, which the Post obtained from Giuliani, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fbi-investigating-hunter-biden-burisma-emails-foreign-intelligence-operation-2020-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">were part of a foreign influence operation</a>.</p><p>These episodes are not known to be part of the federal criminal probe into Giuliani, but they highlight his repeated disregard for counterintelligence officials&#39; warnings that a foreign government was using him to further its own agenda.</p><p>Michael Cohen, a former Trump lawyer who was also raided by the FBI and is currently serving out a sentence for an array of crimes, put forward a blunt assessment of Giuliani&#39;s mounting legal troubles this week.</p><p>&#34;We have no idea how expansive this investigation is going to ultimately reveal itself because Rudy&#39;s an idiot,&#34; he <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/video-michael-cohen-giuliani-idiot-who-will-flip-on-trump-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">told CNN</a>. &#34;And that&#39;s the problem. Rudy drinks too much, Rudy behaves in such an erratic manner that who knows what&#39;s on those telephones or what&#39;s on his computers.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/how-rudy-giuliani-landed-in-doj-crosshairs-what-to-know-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Ce1hnbpJ8R4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 30 Apr 2021 19:11:34 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/601990adee136f00183a9d5a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"d11c7846a1de63b7caa9d8e7e68755a0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn93@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-21-201_659e0045e9e28007.webp","destWidth":4338,"destHeight":3254,"sourceBytes":1554344,"destBytes":1554344,"author":"ssheth@businessinsider.com (Sonam Sheth)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/605738c3cad7d300183f835b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn75@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-22-306_1fc22ec463811999.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn7@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-22-782_3ec33dbd5819f167.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn99@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-21-775_90d707d374ff31ee.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ce1hnbpJ8R4:mnO9TLSoxD0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn41@2020_1/2021/05/01/06-42-25-706_1def3b5847782295.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Ce1hnbpJ8R4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn3@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-26-496_2ff136e81beedca3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324322},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"SCOTT GALLOWAY: College has soared in price with few changes to justify the cost - and the pandemic is finally challenging America's obsession with it","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/scott-galloway-what-america-gets-right-and-wrong-college-education-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60624250c9d73b00186e90c6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"AP20281389054160\" height=\"2746\" width=\"3661\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Upward mobility in the US is still being stifled as Ivy Leagues continue to cater to the 1%, while second-tier schools are slowly being erased.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Seth Wenig, File</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Scott Galloway is a bestselling author and professor of marketing at NYU Stern.</li>\n<li>The following is a recent blog post, republished with permission, that originally ran on his blog, &#34;<a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\">No Mercy / No Malice</a>.&#34;</li>\n<li>In it, Galloway says the elite educational institutes are still profiting while second-teir schools struggle. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Higher education is the most important industry in America. It&#39;s the vaccine against the inequities of capitalism, the lubricant of upward economic mobility, and the midwife of gene therapies and search engines. College graduates lead longer, healthier, and more prosperous lives. University research provides the raw material for corporate innovation. Our institutions call to our shores the best and the brightest from around the world, many of whom stay to make America a stronger nation, and form connective tissue with their home countries.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c3c9e35c46f0018c0ba69?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway\" height=\"936\" width=\"1560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Higher ed presents a promise for America and the world. But every year, my industry falls further from that promise. The underpinnings of that view are simple and static: Higher ed has increased its prices by 1,400% since the late 1970s, but the product has not appreciably changed - the biggest cost driver is administrative bloat. And, rather than catalyzing economic mobility, US higher ed is stifling it. At 38 of the top 100 colleges in America, including five of the Ivies, there are <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/01/18/upshot/some-colleges-have-more-students-from-the-top-1-percent-than-the-bottom-60.html\">more students</a> from the top 1% of income earning households than there are from the bottom 60%.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c3d1e35c46f0018c0ba6a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway 2\" height=\"642\" width=\"1560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Yet, higher ed&#39;s brand strength (nobody donates $20 million to name a building on Apple&#39;s campus), cash reserves (among elite institutions), and stranglehold on the American psyche have insulated it from disruption for decades. The litmus test for success - and for determining your role in our species - is if your daughter graduates from college (and which one). Suzy might be a heroin addict, but if she&#39;s at Dartmouth, all is forgiven.</p><p>Last year, we predicted the pandemic would be the fist of stone that finally meets higher ed&#39;s glass jaw. Were we correct regarding the coming storm? Or were we alarmist, underestimating institutional strength (or rather, inertia)? The answer is … yes.</p><h2>K-Shaped (college) recovery</h2><p>As we begin to emerge from COVID-19 (God&#39;s ears), American colleges look like the rest of America. Specifically, the fifth installment of the Hunger Games franchise, wherein our society engages in the idolatry of economic winners, everyone else hopes to survive, and many meet a gruesome end.</p><p>The most selective schools received 17% more <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/20/us/colleges-covid-applicants.html\">applications</a> than last year, and the elite of the elite saw even greater increases: Yale, 33%; Harvard, 43%; MIT 66%. The rich are getting richer.</p><p>These schools (and the media) have emphasized that the increases in applications include record numbers from poor students and students of color - at UCLA, for example, overall applications rose 28%, but the school received 48% more applications from Black students. The result is that top schools are reporting their <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/17/us/minority-acceptance-ivy-league-cornell.html\">most diverse cohort of admitted students in history</a>.</p><p>Two factors drove these increases: dropping the standardized test requirement, and the increased attention paid to racial and economic justice over the past year. Few people are in a position to make as immediate and tangible of an impact on the lives of promising young students from disadvantaged backgrounds as are elite college admissions officials. In 2021, they leveraged this power.</p><p>Widen the lens, however, and this trend starts to look less encouraging. Admission to a top school can be life changing, but in a country that graduates over 3.5 million people from high school every year, the 1,700-person freshman class at Harvard is immaterial. Over the past 30 years, the number of seats at Ivy League schools has increased only 14%, while the number of high school graduates has <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/harvard-and-its-peers-should-be-embarrassed-about-how-few-students-they-educate/2021/04/08/3c0be99c-97cb-11eb-b28d-bfa7bb5cb2a5_story.html\">expanded by 44%</a>. The Ivy League sits on a total endowment of $140 billion, and shares this wealth with just <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/941545/ivy-league-students-class/#statisticContainer\">17,000 freshmen</a> each year.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c3de935c46f0018c0ba6d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway 3\" height=\"741\" width=\"1560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>A year ago, I <a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/post-corona-higher-ed/\">predicted</a> that these schools would leverage their extraordinary brand strength and the forced adoption of distance learning technology to partner with big tech and radically expand their class sizes. &#34;In 10 years,&#34; I told <a href=\"https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/05/scott-galloway-future-of-college.html\">New York magazine</a>, &#34;it&#39;s feasible to think that MIT doesn&#39;t welcome 1,000 freshmen to campus; it welcomes 10,000.&#34;</p><p>I was wrong. The leadership and alumni of elite universities continue to register tremendous psychic reward from the Hermes-ification of their institutions, versus any remaining claim of public service. Expect another round of undue self-congratulation from these schools in the fall - but look closely, as the anticipated record-setting enrolled student numbers this year simply reflect the record number of deferred enrollments last year.</p><h2>Zombie schools walking</h2><p>Widen the lens a bit more, and the picture gets worse. While applications were up at elite schools, they were way <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/20/us/colleges-covid-applicants.html\">down</a> at second-tier schools. Applications for federal financial aid are also <a href=\"https://www.marketplace.org/2021/03/18/financial-aid-applications-are-down-does-that-mean-fewer-college-students/\">down</a> 9%, which suggests that college ambition among poor and working class kids is declining. In a society where college degrees are the vaccine against inequality, this is disturbing news. Declining college attendance among those who would benefit most is a <a href=\"https://www.baltimoresun.com/coronavirus/bs-md-fda-inspection-report-emergent-biosolutions-baltimore-2021-20210421-xizdfxwipbahvhki2t2zulld4i-story.html\">contamination of the vaccine supply</a>.</p><p>The prediction that generated the most controversy we&#39;ve inspired (with my shirt on) was when we <a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/post-corona-higher-ed/\">wrote</a> in April 2020: &#34;We&#39;ll see a culling among universities … we&#39;re going to see dozens, maybe hundreds, of universities not reopen.&#34; And we named names. In May, we <a href=\"https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/05/scott-galloway-future-of-college.html\">predicted</a>: &#34;There will be a lot of zombie universities. Alumni will step in to help. They&#39;ll cut costs to figure out how to stay alive, but they&#39;ll effectively be the walking dead.&#34; Within 72 hours I received my first, second, and third cease and desist letters from universities we said were likely to perish. The threats of legal action have tempered my actions and caused a number of sleepless nights. The last sentence is a lie.</p><p>So far, though, there has not been a rash of post-pandemic college closings. Some schools have <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/education/2021/01/28/covid-19-colleges-concordia-new-york-education/4302980001/\">closed</a>: MacMurray, Mills, Concordia, and Holy Family, all small schools with long histories and proud traditions - but also financial weaknesses that left them exposed to the pandemic&#39;s impact.</p><p>Many more schools have similar weaknesses. One <a href=\"https://www.wbur.org/edify/2020/05/08/higher-education-financial-crisis\">study</a> found that one-third of private colleges are at &#34;high risk&#34; of financial failure. (The study was never formally released, however, thanks to cease and desist letters from many of those schools … #feelyou.) COVID-related costs, coupled with the decline in applications, portend more problems. Many of these schools will graduate more Hunger Games contestants, but the odds are not in their favor.</p><p>Bankruptcy, as Hemmingway observed, happens two ways: &#34;Gradually, then suddenly.&#34;</p><h2>Wildlings</h2><p>While the lords of American higher ed fortify their walls, and the erasures of second-tier castles multiply, there is a gathering force about to ignite a fire the North has never seen. Last year, I believed the change would occur on the supply side, with expanded enrollments at the top schools. It now looks as if the demand side will change the game: Employers are rethinking certification.</p><p>From <a href=\"https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1208841343440568320\">Elon</a> to <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2018/08/16/15-companies-that-no-longer-require-employees-to-have-a-college-degree.html#:~:text=%20Google%2C%20Apple%20and%2012%20other%20companies%20that,6%20Apple.%20%207%20Chipotle.%20%20More%20\">Apple</a>, some of the most admired employers are dropping the college degree requirement from more and more jobs. Over 130 companies have committed to accepting Google-certified courses as equivalent to credits earned at traditional four-year colleges. More than <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/13/google-announces-certificates-in-data-project-management-and-ux.html\">250,000</a> people took Google&#39;s IT certificate program in its first two years - and 57% of them did not have a college degree.</p><p>Similarly, Amazon <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Austen/status/1381952098900774919\">announced</a> a partnership with Lambda School, launching a nine-month, full-time training program in software engineering, designed to put graduates in jobs with an average base salary of $80,000. Students are not obligated to pay anything upfront; instead, they pay based on their salary after graduation. Again: no college degree required.</p><p>Here in Florida, Governor DeSantis has <a href=\"https://www.floridatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/03/22/desantis-proposes-75-million-initiatives-boost-florida-workforce/4797937001/\">proposed</a> using $75 million in federal COVID relief funds to invest in vocational training programs. There&#39;s a <a href=\"https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20210318005265/en/U.S.-Skilled-Trades-Labor-Shortage-Heightens-as-In-Demand-Jobs-Remain-Unfilled-the-Longest\">scarcity</a> of skilled tradespeople, and those are good paying, secure jobs - it will be a long time before robots replace electricians and plumbers.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c3fbd35c46f0018c0ba7b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway 4\" height=\"687\" width=\"1560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>This is bad news for schools without the global brand equity of the elites. They are being unbundled, piece by piece, just as newspapers were dissected (classifieds, movie listings, news, sports) and sold for parts to benign billionaires. Today, we have a handful of elite newspapers that are thriving, a wasteland of dead/dying second-tier papers, and a roiling maelstrom of tech-enabled news sources serving the mass market. Since 2004, two thousand newspapers have shuttered. It could be as bloody among universities.</p><h2>Break it all</h2><p>As bad as this looks for America&#39;s second-tier, four-year colleges, it may be great news for America. This unbundling presents the opportunity to <a href=\"https://youtu.be/J-rxmk6zPxA\">break the wheel</a> of four-year college dominance over the American Dream.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c401c35c46f0018c0ba7e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway 5\" height=\"945\" width=\"1560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>That dream itself is at risk. Wealth is being hoarded by the old, which has left young people adrift and unattached. We need to find ways to invest in the non-college bound, and create on-ramps into the corporate economy without the ritual of a $200,000 college education.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c405d35c46f0018c0ba82?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway 6\" height=\"936\" width=\"1560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>These programs could also liberate education from its ageism. College is the most ageist sector in the US, a huge industry set up to serve 18-24 year olds. Even graduate schools are designed to appeal to twenty-somethings. Yet our innovation economy means people will need new skills at every phase of life.</p><p>One lesson can be taken from universities, though. Just as they dropped the requirement of standardized tests, and registered enormous progress around diversity and inclusion, America can register the same unlock if US corporations broaden the on-ramp to a better life by dropping their fetishization of the college degree.</p><p>Life is so rich,</p><p>Scott</p><p>P.S. A hero of mine joined me on the <a href=\"https://pod.link/profg/episode/45256bbfa0f4b763bcae9b5f17e0541a\">Prof G</a> Pod this week - Senator Al Franken. Franken discusses the state of play regarding our political ecosystem and how Americans are separated into two different information universes. He also shares how he got his start in comedy, as one of the original seven writers at Saturday Night Live.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/scott-galloway-what-america-gets-right-and-wrong-college-education-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Xi77KQ1PEbI:Mtfhc1BiiL0:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Xi77KQ1PEbI:Mtfhc1BiiL0:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Xi77KQ1PEbI:Mtfhc1BiiL0:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Xi77KQ1PEbI:Mtfhc1BiiL0:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Xi77KQ1PEbI:Mtfhc1BiiL0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Xi77KQ1PEbI:Mtfhc1BiiL0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Xi77KQ1PEbI\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 30 Apr 2021 19:08:47 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/60624250c9d73b00186e90c6?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"f1c8521160c560291008c8f50e38b529","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn3@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-20-636_571a2b6bd02a7539.webp","destWidth":3661,"destHeight":2746,"sourceBytes":50336,"destBytes":50336,"author":"insider@insider.com (Scott Galloway)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/60624250c9d73b00186e90c6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn3@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-20-636_571a2b6bd02a7539.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c3c9e35c46f0018c0ba69?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-22-314_85c11bc894a03369.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c3d1e35c46f0018c0ba6a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn8@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-25-366_7ca8e6451935b049.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c3de935c46f0018c0ba6d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn85@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-26-028_3f0fd2adb587e9ad.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c3fbd35c46f0018c0ba7b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn67@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-21-385_bb87badced17e770.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c401c35c46f0018c0ba7e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn75@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-21-568_635f856f1cf8f284.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c405d35c46f0018c0ba82?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn5@2020_1/2021/05/01/06-42-23-743_f136cc53f3ee9e88.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Xi77KQ1PEbI:Mtfhc1BiiL0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn60@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-883_6d5b526b0bb59815.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Xi77KQ1PEbI:Mtfhc1BiiL0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn71@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-24-326_b7920ab37d3150d4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Xi77KQ1PEbI:Mtfhc1BiiL0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn16@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-25-926_148ac2aea8b307b7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Xi77KQ1PEbI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn51@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-24-248_f51369806b61ffe7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324326},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"Disneyland is reopening today after being closed for over a year. These are the most expensive spots in Disney Parks, including Cinderella Castle Suite.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/disney-parks-disneyland-world-expensive-exclusive-resort-walt-cinderella-2019-4","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/hsO5Wlkr-jZbcmOYf.html\" width=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" style=\"position:absolute;\" allow=\"fullscreen\"></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/disney\">Disney</a> park <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/disney-world-expensive-middle-class-2018-12\">tickets are getting more expensive</a>, but some experiences at <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/disney-world\">Disney World</a> and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/disneyland\">Disneyland</a> come with their own price tags, especially if you&#39;re looking for the royal treatment.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>An 11-course meal at Victoria and Albert&#39;s will cost $250, while a night in the Cinderella Castle Suite is so exclusive, not even money can book your stay - you&#39;ll have to get an invitation. </strong></li>\n<li>Watch the video above to see just how luxurious a trip to Disney can be.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider&#39;s homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>We all know Disney parks aren&#39;t really affordable to begin with, but if you&#39;re looking to sprinkle a little extra Disney elegance into your visit, there are plenty of ways to experience the magic like a true king or queen. A nice queen, don&#39;t worry.</p><h2>Here&#39;s our list of the most exclusive spots in America&#39;s Disney parks.</h2><h3>1. Cinderella Castle Suite</h3><p>First up, the Cinderella Castle Suite. At the top of the iconic Cinderella Castle in Magic Kingdom, there&#39;s a private suite hidden inside. With towering princess beds, an ornate bathroom, and &#34;Cinderella&#34; props throughout, the suite is definitely fit for a royal. A night&#39;s stay here is so exclusive, you can&#39;t actually book it. The suite is by invite only. But it&#39;s rumored Disney turned down an offer of $40,000 for a one-night stay. Some lucky fans have scored a stay by winning various contests. Special guests at the Cinderella Suite have included Tom Cruise and Mariah Carey.</p><h3>2. Imagineer Dinner</h3><p>You&#39;ve probably heard of the Disney Imagineers - or the masterminds behind the rides, the shows, the music, pretty much everything that&#39;s cool at Disney parks - and if you&#39;ve ever wanted to meet one, we&#39;ll do you one better. How about a dinner with an Imagineer? Once a month, you can learn from one of these Disney legends over a four-course meal at Cítricos in the Grand Floridian Resort. The only thing is, you won&#39;t know who you&#39;re eating with until you get there. The experience will set you back $89 and is limited to guests 14 and older.</p><h3>3. Victoria and Albert&#39;s </h3><p>Located in Disney&#39;s Grand Floridian Resort and Spa, Victoria and Albert&#39;s is probably the ritziest restaurant at Disney World. With only 18 tables, reservations are required, and a fancy dress code is strictly enforced. But getting all glammed up is definitely worth it for their chef&#39;s tasting menu. The 11-course meal comes in at $250. But if you&#39;re wanting something even more exclusive, you can book a table for up to eight people in a completely separate and private space, in the Queen Victoria Room.</p><h3>4. Morimoto Asia</h3><p>Morimoto Asia isn&#39;t as high-end as Victoria and Albert&#39;s, but it does have a little something special up its sleeve. &#34;Iron Chef&#34; Masaharu Morimoto opened the glitzy restaurant in 2015. Located in Disney Springs, it specializes in Pan-Asian cuisine. Their most exclusive dish is the Japanese A5 Wagyu beef. The beef has the highest rating for Wagyu and is imported from Japan. Each ounce costs $25, but there&#39;s an order minimum of 3 ounces, so be prepared to pay about $75 at least. They also have a Toku-Jyo Sashimi Platter that runs for $100.</p><h3>5. Bibbidi Bobbidi Boutique</h3><p>Looking to spoil your little ones? Hop over to Cinderella&#39;s Castle in Magic Kingdom to the Bibbidi Bobbidi Boutique. Here, one of the Fairy Godmother&#39;s apprentices will transform your kiddo into a knight or one of their favorite princesses. The all-in package for knights costs $80, but for Disney princesses, a full transformation starts at $450. It includes a hair styling, makeover, manicure, gown, and tiara. You can get princess shoes but for an extra cost. These magic makeovers require a reservation and are only available for kids 3 to 12.</p><h3>6. Golden Oak Residences </h3><p>Four miles away from Magic Kingdom is the super-exclusive gated community called Golden Oak. Three-hundred homes, each with a little Disney flair, make up eight neighborhoods. But living so close to all the Disney magic doesn&#39;t come cheap. Each one runs for about $2.3 million. All Golden Oak residents get access to a luxurious clubhouse complete with a pool, gym, and spa. Another perk: Markham&#39;s Restaurant. You have to be a resident here to experience all their Disney-themed meals.</p><h3>7. Club 33</h3><p>A luxury Disney experience doesn&#39;t stop in Florida. Over at Disneyland in California, Club 33 has been serving an exclusive group of fans since 1967. Located in New Orleans Square, the club&#39;s existence was once secret, but now it&#39;s pretty well known although few get to experience it. Reportedly, the initiation fee runs between $25,000 and $100,000. Members pay an additional annual fee from $12,500 to $30,000 depending on how exclusive their membership is. And for those willing to foot that bill, membership does come with a couple perks, like the swanky restaurant Le Grand Salon and the lounge attached to it, which is the only place that serves alcohol in Disneyland.</p><h3>8. Lilly Belle Train</h3><p>Anybody can ride the steam-powered train of Disneyland&#39;s railroad, but you might not know that there&#39;s a separate train that runs only occasionally. The Lilly Belle car is named after Walt Disney&#39;s wife, Lillian, and apparently it&#39;s the last remaining car from the opening day of the park back in 1955. It doesn&#39;t run every day, but when it does, you can ride it for free, but you have to be one of the first 14 people in line, so get there bright and early. But for the rest of us late risers, the $85 Grand Circle Tour will get you a peek of the train as well.</p><h3>9. Walt Disney&#39;s Apartment</h3><p>Back in 1954, as Disneyland was under construction, Walt Disney wanted a place where he could watch over his project. So he had this private 500-square-foot apartment built. The once secret space is located on the second floor of the Fire House on Main Street. It&#39;s decorated by Disney&#39;s original set designer and looks exactly like how Walt Disney left it. You can&#39;t actually stay here, but for $109 per person, the Walk in Walt&#39;s Disneyland Footsteps tour will get you a little closer to the man himself.</p><p><em>EDITOR&#39;S NOTE: This video was originally published in April 2019.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"SpaceX told to suspend work on NASA's moon-lander project until a challenge by Jeff Bezos' rival space company is resolved","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacex-ordered-to-stop-work-on-nasa-moon-lander-project-pending-challenges-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6ff934af8d001859a627?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Jeff Bezos Elon Musk\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">MANDEL NGAN/AFP via Getty/Axel Springer</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The SpaceX moon-lander project is on hold pending review by the Government Accountability Office.</li>\n<li>NASA ordered the halt after competing firms Dynetics and Jeff Bezos&#39; Blue Origin filed complaints.</li>\n<li>The space agency initially said it would choose two companies before awarding SpaceX a sole contract.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>SpaceX&#39;s moon-lander project for NASA has been put on hold after rival bidders Dynetics and Jeff Bezos&#39; Blue Origin filed challenges with the Government Accountability Office.</p><p>The US space agency told SpaceX to halt its work on the project, which aims to land humans on the moon as early as 2024, until the dispute can be resolved. </p><p>&#34;NASA instructed SpaceX that progress on the HLS contract has been suspended until GAO resolves all outstanding litigation related to this procurement,&#34; the space agency said in a statement Friday reported by <a href=\"https://spacenews.com/dynetics-hls-protest-argues-nasa-should-have-revised-competition-after-budget-shortfall/\">Jeff Foust for Space News</a>.</p><p>In Dynetics&#39; complaint, which was co-signed by Blue Origin, the company argues that NASA should have withdrawn its request for bids for the lunar project once it became clear it didn&#39;t have enough funding to proceed with two companies, as it had originally planned.</p><p>In awarding to SpaceX alone, Dynetics argued, NASA chose &#34;the most anti-competitive and high risk option available.&#34;</p><p>SpaceX received the exclusive $2.9 billion contract earlier this month, after bidding a much lower price than the competitors offered, <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/atoms/files/option-a-source-selection-statement-final.pdf\">NASA said</a>.</p><p>The move was met with <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacex-nasa-contract-industry-reaction-blue-origin-space-moon-2021-4\">skepticism from the Blue Origin team</a>, who filed a 50-page protest with the GAO.</p><p>In a statement to Insider earlier this week, Bezos&#39; company described the award as &#34;flawed,&#34; adding that NASA &#34;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-elon-musk-spacex-nasa-contract-flawed-2021-4\">moved the goal posts</a> at the last minute.&#34;</p><p>In its filing, Blue Origin said NASA set a project target cost of $6 billion - more than double SpaceX&#39;s $2.9 billion proposal.</p><p>The company said NASA negotiated a proposed price with SpaceX, but not with Blue Origin, which it said was unfair.</p><p>NASA <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/atoms/files/option-a-source-selection-statement-final.pdf\">responded</a> by saying budget concerns and lack of Congressional funding meant it had to go with a single competitor. The agency reportedly received about a quarter of the total $3.3 billion budget allocation it requested for 2021.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"How to check 'League of Legends' server status if you can't connect to the game","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/league-of-legends-server-status","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c621434af8d001859a5c5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"PC gaming on desktop computer\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>If &#34;League of Legends&#34; isn&#39;t working properly, it may be an issue with Riot Games&#39; servers.\n<p class=\"copyright\">chee gin tan/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li aria-level=\"1\">You can check &#34;League of Legends&#39;&#34; server status through Riot Games&#39; website or Twitter account.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">If there aren&#39;t issues on with &#34;League&#39;s&#34; servers, you should troubleshoot your own internet connection.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">For example, try resetting your router and then opening &#34;League of Legends&#34; again.,</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Visit Insider&#39;s Tech Reference library for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/multiplayer-games\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Multiplayer online games</a> like &#34;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/league-of-legends\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">League of Legends</a>&#34; can be fun, except when you run into server issues and are dropped from your game without warning. When that happens, you can troubleshoot to fix the problem, but first you should check to see if the problems are coming from Riot Games&#39; own &#34;League of Legends&#34; servers.</p><h2>How to check the &#39;League of Legends&#39; server status</h2><p>There are two ways to check &#34;League&#39;s&#34; server status:</p><p><strong>1.</strong> Check the <a href=\"https://status.riotgames.com/?locale=en_US\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Riot Games service status website</a>. If there&#39;s an issue, you should see a notice under &#34;Current Messages.&#34;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c5ab434af8d001859a5a7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"League of Legends server status 1\" height=\"1167\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You&#39;ll be notified of any server issues under &#34;Current Messages.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Devon Delfino/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>2. </strong>Check the <a href=\"https://twitter.com/RiotSupport\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Riot Games support Twitter account</a>. The developer may post a tweet before it can update the website (though it posts to both areas when something goes wrong), so it&#39;s worth checking both.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c5d2d34af8d001859a5af?format=jpeg\" alt=\"League of Legends server status 3\" height=\"1214\" width=\"2574\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The @RiotSupport Twitter account may tweet out any server issues.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Devon Delfino/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><aside class=\"quick-tip headline-regular\"><p><strong>Quick note</strong>: In some cases, you might also get an error message when you try to start the game, saying there&#39;s a server outage. This is especially true if the server goes down because Riot is performing maintenance.</p></aside><h2>How to troubleshoot &#39;League of Legends&#39; internet issues</h2><p>There are a few options for troubleshooting: restarting the game, resetting your router, and exiting out of other internet tasks or downloads. Here&#39;s how to do the first two methods:</p><p><strong>Restart the game:</strong></p><ul><li>On a PC, press Ctrl+Alt+Delete/Esc to force-quit. Next, select &#34;Task Manager&#34; and then select the &#34;League of Legends&#34; app and hit &#34;End Task,&#34; then relaunch the game as usual.</li><li>On a Mac, press Option+Command+Esc to force-quit the application, then select the &#34;League of Legends&#34; app in the window and hit &#34;Force Quit.&#34;</li></ul><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c5de335c46f0018c0bb45?format=jpeg\" alt=\"League of Legends server status 4\" height=\"1415\" width=\"2540\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>On a Mac, try force quitting the League of Legends application.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Devon Delfino/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>Reset your router:</strong></p><ul><li>Unplug your router from the power supply and wait for 30 seconds before plugging it back in. Once you&#39;ve done this, restart &#34;League.&#34;</li></ul><p>For more tips on how to fix a faulty internet connection, check out our article, &#34;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/wifi-problems\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">10 ways to troubleshoot and fix any Wi-Fi problems you&#39;re encountering</a>.&#34;</p><bi-shortcode 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"Secretary of State Antony Blinken heading to Ukraine to show support after Russia sparked fears of an invasion","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/blinken-heading-ukraine-after-russia-sparked-fears-of-an-invasion-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c63faf22c6b00185db10e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Biden and Secretary of State Antony Blinken\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Secretary of State nominee Antony Blinken speaks after being introduced by President-elect Joe Biden as he introduces key foreign policy and national security nominees and appointments at the Queen Theatre on November 24, 2020 in Wilmington, Delaware.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mark Makela/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>America&#39;s top diplomat is heading to Ukraine next week.</li>\n<li>This trip comes on the heels of a Russian military buildup that sparked fears of an invasion.</li>\n<li>The State Department said the trip is about showing support to Ukraine against Russian aggression.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Secretary of State Antony Blinken is set to visit Ukraine next week as a sign of support after a recent buildup of Russia troops at the Ukrainian border that raised fears of a potential invasion. </p><p>Blinken will meet with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on the trip, which the State Department in a statement said is designed to &#34;reaffirm unwavering U.S. support for Ukraine&#39;s sovereignty and territorial integrity in the face of Russia&#39;s ongoing aggression.&#34;</p><p>&#34;He will also encourage continued progress on Ukraine&#39;s institutional reform agenda, particularly anti-corruption action, which is key to securing Ukraine&#39;s democratic institutions, economic prosperity, and Euro-Atlantic future,&#34; the statement added. This will be Blinken&#39;s third trip abroad since becoming the top US diplomat. </p><p>Ukraine has been fighting a war against Kremlin-backed rebels in the eastern Donbass region since 2014, the same year that Russian President Vladimir Putin unilaterally annexed Crimea. The bloody conflict has claimed more than 13,000 lives, and remains a point of contention between Moscow and the West. </p><p>More recently, Russia amassed roughly 100,000 troops along Ukraine&#39;s eastern border and in Crimea, raising alarm bells across Europe and in Washington. After weeks of tensions over the buildup, Putin in a speech last Thursday warned that anyone who threatens Russia&#39;s security will <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-warns-against-provoking-russia-amid-fears-invade-ukraine-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b29c05064930b7c7cdcc983861d1836c\">&#34;regret&#34;</a> it.</p><p>The next day, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-suddenly-says-its-pulling-back-troops-from-ukraine-borders-2021-4\">Russia abruptly announced</a> it was pulling its troops back from the Ukrainian border. &#34;The reduction of troops on our border proportionally reduces tension,&#34; Zelensky said in <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ZelenskyyUa/status/1385235227212136449?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1385235227212136449%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2Fnews%2Fworld-europe-568427632763\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"e847ba8399323a143f2a15959e1515a9\">a tweet</a> responding to the announcement. The Ukrainian leader added that Ukraine is &#34;always vigilant&#34; but &#34;welcomes any steps to decrease the military presence&#34; and &#34;deescalate the situation&#34; in Donbass</p><p>Ukraine has increasingly been portrayed by foreign policy experts and analysts as <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/13/opinions/can-america-still-promote-democracy-ukraine-bociurkiw/index.html\">the frontline in the fight to uphold and strengthen democracy</a> - an issue President Joe Biden has repeatedly emphasized since becoming president. </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original
