border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/fFOLYRpFKcg\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 30 Apr 2021 19:20:50 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608c46d935c46f0018c0bab0?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"b40db5dbc25c1b89327eb58d49913b80","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn63@2020_1/2021/05/01/06-42-21-199_0725a73d8c4cfc0e.webp","destWidth":1034,"destHeight":775,"sourceBytes":64614,"destBytes":64614,"author":"mfox@businessinsider.com (Matthew Fox)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608c46cb35c46f0018c0baaf?format=jpeg":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fFOLYRpFKcg:pTWejxs2lQ0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn49@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-25-538_f9f4edd1bdd92da9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fFOLYRpFKcg:pTWejxs2lQ0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn65@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-23-259_66216a48bb322a8a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fFOLYRpFKcg:pTWejxs2lQ0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn67@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-26-213_5f4dcd9594a213ac.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/fFOLYRpFKcg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn96@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-21-922_181efbaa2e9b6c61.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324320},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"Americans' personal income shot up 21.1% in March, a record dating back to at least 1946","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-income-march-spending-stimulus-economy-covid-checks-americans-biden-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/604a436bf196be0018beedb1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"shopping\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Passers-by examine a storefront window on Boston&#39;s Newbury Street shopping district. Personal income and spending both jumped in March.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Steven Senne, File via AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Personal income for Americans climbed by 21.1% in March, the Commerce Department said Friday. </li>\n<li>It&#39;s the highest on record in data that goes all the way back to 1946; spending was up by 4.2%.</li>\n<li>The income jump was supported by the $1.9 trillion stimulus signed into law by President Biden.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Income for American households in March surged by the largest amount ever, fueled by massive fiscal stimulus released by the US government to limit the economic damage from the COVID-19 health crisis. </p><p>Personal income soared by an estimated 21.1% last month, or by $4.21 trillion, <a href=\"https://www.bea.gov/news/2021/personal-income-and-outlays-march-2021\">the Bureau of Economic Analysis said Friday</a>. The figure compares to a 20.3% increase expected in an Econoday survey of economists. The March figure marked a swing from February&#39;s income decline of 7%. </p><p>The monthly income leap was the biggest on record in data that goes back to 1946. </p><p>&#34;Incomes soared as a result of the stimulus payments made under the March relief bill,&#34; said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, in a Friday note, referring to the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-biden-signs-trillion-covid-relief-package-checks-direct-payments-2021-3\">$1.9 trillion stimulus package</a> that President Joe Biden signed into law, which unleashed $1,400 checks to most Americans. </p><p>Income readings &#34;will correct in both April and May, but income from employment will rise much more strongly over the next few months and, in any event, most of the payments have not yet been spent,&#34; wrote Shepherdson. </p><p>The Commerce Department&#39;s report also showed that spending, or personal consumption, leapt by 4.2% last month. &#34;The jump in March spending ... was clearly signaled by the retail sales numbers,&#34; Shepherdson said. </p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-retail-sales-march-stimulus-reopening-vaccination-economic-recovery-spending-2021-4\">Retail sales pushed higher by 9.8% in March</a> to a record $619.1 billion, the Census Bureau said earlier this month.  </p><p>Jason Furman, a Harvard economics professor and chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers to former President Barack Obama, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/jasonfurman/status/1388111321229561861\">wrote on Twitter</a> about the unique nature of the report. He noted that the real disposable personal income shooting up 23% was a one-time bump attributable to stimulus checks, and that it normally takes about two years for real personal consumption expenditures to shoot up by 3.6%.</p><p>The <a href=\"https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/blog/2021/04/30/new-data-releases-show-the-importance-of-government-support-during-the-pandemic/\">White House commented</a> that the report shows the importance of government support during the pandemic. It said the largest contribution to income during the pandemic came from government benefits, which were up over $300 billion over the month (almost $4 trillion at an annualized rate). Americans&#39; saving rate of 28% was the second-highest on record, it noted, and much higher than the average pre-crisis saving rate of 7.5%. </p><p>Sen. Bernie Sanders wrote of the report <a href=\"https://twitter.com/SenSanders/status/1388165020656279553\">on Twitter</a> that &#34;We are BEGINNING to create an economy that works for all. But more must be done,&#34; and called for an increase of the minimum wage, universal healthcare, lower prescription drug costs, student-debt forgiveness, and higher taxes on corporations and the wealthy.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-income-march-spending-stimulus-economy-covid-checks-americans-biden-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=LJtZYwiprTw:Jh1hjtzdCkE:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LJtZYwiprTw:Jh1hjtzdCkE:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=LJtZYwiprTw:Jh1hjtzdCkE:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/LJtZYwiprTw\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 30 Apr 2021 19:33:26 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/60494bf69942cf001865db71?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"06d539ac00fdad5191858a9e9d54fb45","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn54@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-20-972_15b907d9e5f92447.webp","destWidth":1885,"destHeight":1414,"sourceBytes":142558,"destBytes":142558,"author":"insider@insider.com (Carla Mozée)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/604a436bf196be0018beedb1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn47@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-22-525_11927d7efe5826f6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LJtZYwiprTw:Jh1hjtzdCkE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn89@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-25-778_a0fc3deeebfa2e24.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LJtZYwiprTw:Jh1hjtzdCkE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn18@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-743_2efcdc6bb3713014.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LJtZYwiprTw:Jh1hjtzdCkE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn67@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-25-774_fd3fb9229ddda6fb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/LJtZYwiprTw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn62@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-23-217_ca0f4165d74a8663.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324316},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"Watch SpaceX's Crew-1 astronauts plummet to an ocean landing early Sunday, ending the longest human spaceflight in NASA history","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/watch-spacex-nasa-crew2-astronaut-mission-splashdown-landing-ocean-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fac5bbb98669500182b5820?format=jpeg\" alt=\"spacex nasa crew 1 mission 4x3\" height=\"1437\" width=\"1917\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Flying aboard SpaceX&#39;s Crew-1 mission for NASA are astronauts (from left) Mike Hopkins, Soichi Noguchi, Shannon Walker, and Victor Glover.\n<p class=\"copyright\">SpaceX; NASA; Samantha Lee/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-cant-sleep-before-spacex-astronaut-launches-2021-4\">SpaceX&#39;s</a> Crew-1 mission for <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacexs-new-astronaut-flight-for-nasa-has-reached-the-iss-2021-4\">NASA</a> is set to fly four <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacexs-new-astronaut-flight-for-nasa-has-reached-the-iss-2021-4\">astronauts</a> back to Earth early on Sunday.</li>\n<li>The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/astronauts-space-station-flew-spacex-crew-dragon-to-new-port-2021-4\">Crew Dragon spaceship</a> must plummet at high speeds, then deploy parachutes to land in the ocean.</li>\n<li>Watch NASA&#39;s livestream below to see the astronauts board Crew Dragon and fall to Earth.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A gumdrop-shaped fireball is set to plummet through the night skies this weekend.</p><p>SpaceX&#39;s Crew Dragon spaceship, carrying four astronauts for NASA, is scheduled to plow through the atmosphere at 25 times the speed of sound, deploy four parachutes as it approaches the coast of Florida, and then glide to a gentle splashdown in the ocean at about 2:57 a.m. ET on Sunday.</p><p>The spaceship, named Resilience, flew to the International Space Station in November, carrying Shannon Walker, Victor Glover, and Mike Hopkins of NASA, along with Soichi Noguchi of the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency. The astronauts have been living and working in orbit for more than five months.</p><p>Their mission, called Crew-1, officially restored NASA&#39;s ability to launch people into space on a US spacecraft for the first time since the Space Shuttles stopped flying in 2011. Six-month spaceflights have been routine for NASA astronauts launching on Russian Soyuz spaceships, but until now, the US had never flown such long-term missions on its own.</p><p>Crew-1 is also SpaceX&#39;s first routine astronaut flight for NASA. The agency has already purchased five more Crew Dragon missions. The second one, Crew-2, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacex-nasa-launch-crew-2-astronauts-aboard-crew-dragon-endeavour-2021-4\">launched four more astronauts</a> toward the ISS on April 23; they <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacexs-new-astronaut-flight-for-nasa-has-reached-the-iss-2021-4\">reached the station</a> the following morning.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60840c6b1d0b54001913dbde?format=jpeg\" alt=\"nasa space x\" height=\"439\" width=\"586\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>There are 11 people aboard the International Space Station.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Walker, Glover, Hopkins, and Noguchi greeted the new arrivals, but the ISS is now crowded. So on Saturday evening, the Crew-1 team is expected to climb back aboard the Crew Dragon Resilience for the journey home.</p><p>SpaceX has flown humans back to Earth from the ISS once before - on a crewed test flight called Demo-2. In May, that mission rocketed NASA astronauts Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken into orbit. They stayed on the ISS for two months before splashing down in the Gulf of Mexico.</p><p>But during Behnken and Hurley&#39;s return to Earth, a crowd of onlooker boats <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-flag-boat-disrupts-live-nasa-astronaut-spacex-landing-2020-8\">got dangerously close</a> to the spaceship after it splashed down. To prevent that from happening again, SpaceX, NASA, and the Coast Guard plan to secure a 10-mile no-boat perimeter around the Crew-1 splashdown site.</p><p>The Crew-1 return trip was originally scheduled for Wednesday, then for Saturday morning, but NASA has <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasa-updates-live-coverage-of-agency-s-spacex-crew-1-return-to-earth\">delayed</a> it twice after forecasts predicted high winds in the splashdown zones.</p><h2>Watch live as Crew-1 returns to Earth</h2><p>NASA plans to broadcast the nearly nine-hour journey - including the fiery plunge to Earth and the splashdown at the end - via the livestream below, starting at 6 p.m. ET on Saturday.</p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/21X5lGlDOfg\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe><p>The entire descent and landing process is automated, but Hurley advised the Crew-1 astronauts to make sure they&#39;re &#34;staying ahead of the capsule,&#34; according to Hopkins, the mission commander.</p><p>&#34;Preparing for that landing is just going over our procedures and making sure, when we get into that sequence of events, that we&#39;re ready to go, and we&#39;re following right along with all of the automation as it takes us to, hopefully, a safe landing,&#34; Hopkins told reporters in <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q0doXND6lhQ\">a call from the ISS</a> on Monday.</p><p>Walker, Glover, Hopkins, and Noguchi are expected to board the Resilience capsule and close its hatch behind them at 6:20 p.m. ET on Saturday. After about two hours of checkouts, the hooks keeping Resilience attached to the space station should retract at 8:35 p.m. ET, undocking the spaceship from the ISS. The vehicle would then fire its thrusters to back away.</p><p>If all goes well, Resilience is expected to spend the night orbiting Earth and maneuvering into position. Then the capsule is designed to jettison its trunk - a lower section outfitted with fuel tanks, solar panels, and other hardware - which the astronauts would no longer need.</p><p>From there, the Crew-2 astronauts could be in for a bumpy ride.</p><p>&#34;The landing was - I would say it was more than what Doug and I expected,&#34; <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-astronaut-describes-fiery-plunge-in-spacex-crew-dragon-2020-8\">Behnken told reporters</a> after he returned to Earth aboard the spaceship. &#34;I personally was surprised at just how quickly events all transpired.&#34;</p><h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f29edf3f0f4196a6029e398?format=jpeg\" alt=\"crew dragon return reentry demo2 doug hurley bob behnken\" height=\"1345\" width=\"1794\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>NASA astronauts Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley, aboard the Crew Dragon Endeavour spacecraft on August 2, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.reutersconnect.com/all?id=tag%3Areuters.com%2C2020%3Anewsml_RC2T5I9KPSUY&#38;share=true\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/Handout via Reuters</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></h2><p>&#34;It felt like we were inside of an animal,&#34; he added.</p><p>Behnken also said that pivotal moments of the landing process - such as when the capsule separated from its trunk and when the parachutes deployed - felt &#34;very much like getting hit in the back of the chair with a baseball bat.&#34;</p><h2>What to expect as the astronauts plummet to Earth</h2><p>As the Resilience spacecraft approaches Earth, it is expected to fire its thrusters continuously, pushing itself further into the atmosphere.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/541c987b69beddee191753ff?format=jpeg\" alt=\"dragon v2 reentry\" height=\"496\" width=\"902\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An animation of Crew Dragon plowing through the atmosphere.\n<p class=\"copyright\">SpaceX</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Soon, the spaceship should be plummeting through the atmosphere, superheating the material around it to a blistering 3,500 degrees Fahrenheit. At that point in his flight, Behnken said, he could feel the capsule heating up, and the force of Earth&#39;s gravity pulling on him for the first time in two months. It felt like being in a centrifuge, he added.</p><p>The Crew Dragon&#39;s <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacex-nasa-crew-dragon-heat-shield-erosion-2020-9\">heat shield</a> - a collection of heat-resistant tiles that line the spaceship&#39;s underbelly - must deflect that superheated material to protect the astronauts inside. After the Demo-2 landing, NASA and SpaceX found that one of those tiles had worn away more than expected. So SpaceX reinforced the heat shield with stronger materials.</p><p>Once it&#39;s about 18,000 feet above the ocean, Resilience should deploy four parachutes - which brings a &#34;pretty significant jolt,&#34; Behnken said.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/607f3c4544f4540019207d34?format=jpeg\" alt=\"demo-2 splashdown parachutes crew dragon spacex\" height=\"1440\" width=\"1920\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Crew Dragon Endeavour lands in the Gulf of Mexico, returning astronauts Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley to Earth on August 2, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://images.nasa.gov/details-NHQ202008020016\" target=\"_blank\">Bill Ingalls/NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>From there, Resilience should glide to a gentle splashdown in the ocean at 2:57 a.m. ET on Sunday. A recovery crew is expected to retrieve the charred capsule and carry the astronauts to shore.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f736b000ab50d00184ad0ab?format=jpeg\" alt=\"demo2 crew dragon recovery splashdown spacex nasa\" height=\"1181\" width=\"1575\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The SpaceX GO Navigator recovery ship lifts the Crew Dragon capsule Endeavour out of the Gulf of Mexico, off the coast of Pensacola, Florida, on August 2, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahqphoto/50182062843/in/photostream/\" target=\"_blank\">Bill Ingalls/NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>&#34;Landings are always fairly dynamic, particularly with the capsules like this, particularly when the chutes are opening. So that&#39;s always a little bit exciting,&#34; Hopkins said.</p><p>When asked what he&#39;d like to eat upon returning from the ISS, he replied, &#34;If I have an appetite, that&#39;s going to be a bonus.&#34;</p><p><em>This post has been updated with new information.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2021 19:20:09 eaderx13/cdn52@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-23-481_2a3bb495ef16398f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324322},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"Pinterest could jump 40% as active users gain and gross margins increase, CFRA says","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/pinterest-stock-price-q1-analysis-active-users-gross-margins-cfra-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c56ab35c46f0018c0bb1f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pinterest mobile app smartphone logo\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">SOPA Images / Contributor/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>CFRA&#39;s John Freeman says Pinterest is a &#34;strong-buy&#34; and could hit $93 per share.</li>\n<li>The price target implies a potential 40% jump from Friday&#39;s intraday low.</li>\n<li>This is &#34;an attractive entry point for perhaps our favorite in social media long-term,&#34; Freeman wrote.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>CFRA&#39;s John Freeman upgraded <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/pins-stock\">Pinterest</a> to a &#34;strong buy&#34; and maintained his $93 price target in a note to clients on Friday after investors abandoned the firm post-earnings.</p><p>Freeman&#39;s price target implies a potential 40% jump in share prices from Friday&#39;s intraday low of $66.01.</p><p>Pinterest&#39;s revenue grew 78% year-over-year in the first-quarter, beating its own guidance and Wall Street analysts&#39; estimates, but that wasn&#39;t enough to keep the stock from falling.</p><p>Shares of the social media company are down roughly 14% since management released its first-quarter <a href=\"https://investor.pinterestinc.com/investor-overview/default.aspx\">earnings report</a> on April 27.</p><p>CFRA Research&#39;s Freeman says the drop has created &#34;an attractive entry point for perhaps our favorite in social media long-term.&#34;</p><p>While investors may have balked at Pinterest&#39;s inability to grow its monthly active user (MAU) total by more than 9% in the quarter and a GAAP net loss of $22 million, CFRA believes 380 million MAUs along with consistent revenue growth is plenty to consider an investment.</p><p>Pinterest also managed to narrow its GAAP losses by 85% in the first quarter.</p><p>Freeman highlighted rising gross margins that allowed the company to narrow its losses. Gross margins were up 900 bps year-over-year in the first quarter to 73%.</p><p>The analyst also noted Pinterest&#39;s Average Revenue Per User (ARPU), excluding the US, doubled in the first quarter versus the same period a year ago. </p><p>Freeman is forecasting Pinterest&#39;s revenue to hit $3.92 billion by 2022 with earnings per share (EPS) at $2.43.</p><p>The analyst used a 15.5x sales multiple to arrive at his $93 price target.</p><p>Despite the weaker than expected first quarter, analysts remain mostly bullish on shares of Pinterest. The company boasts 35 &#34;buy&#34; ratings, 19 &#34;neutral&#34; ratings, and zero &#34;sell&#34; ratings from analysts.</p><p>Shares of Pinterest traded down 2.98% as of 3:11 p.m. ET on Friday.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c568735c46f0018c0bb1d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"PINS chart\" height=\"661\" width=\"818\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/9ZUm7UPBsRA\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 30 Apr 2021 19:30:31 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608c56b735c46f0018c0bb20?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"0cfe29e83f28e90e9b6882ee81cb384d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn64@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-21-018_4794ad7391861002.webp","destWidth":2214,"destHeight":1660,"sourceBytes":87376,"destBytes":87376,"author":"wdaniel@businessinsider.com (Will Daniel)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608c56ab35c46f0018c0bb1f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn92@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-21-947_f39d4d1650ae9f45.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c568735c46f0018c0bb1d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn98@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-25-816_1770529aa08efaa6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=9ZUm7UPBsRA:pvX2Z9bQu08:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn70@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-23-844_2210116e380e3a22.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=9ZUm7UPBsRA:pvX2Z9bQu08:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn87@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-22-121_976ae62cd1a49be9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=9ZUm7UPBsRA:pvX2Z9bQu08:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn83@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-22-744_968d6b98fccb5f49.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/9ZUm7UPBsRA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn22@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-25-557_d70bff7e31f1a575.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324317},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"Why we eat oysters alive","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/oysters-still-alive-eaten-raw-vibrio-vulnificus-2018-9","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/jthGtISY-jZbcmOYf.html\" width=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" style=\"position:absolute;\" allow=\"fullscreen\"></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/oysters\">Raw oysters</a> are either still alive - or freshly killed - when you eat them. </strong></li>\n<li><strong>Many people think keeping them alive longer makes them safer to eat, but that&#39;s not the full story.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>The risk of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/flesh-eating-bacteria-eating-raw-oysters-florida-man-2018-7\">dying from eating a bad oyster</a> is very low in comparison to dying from other foodborne illnesses such as salmonella.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>Oyster expert Julie Qiu explains the biggest reason we eat oysters alive. </strong></li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><em>Following is the transcript of the video.</em></p><p><strong>David Anderson: &#34;</strong>Wanna know a secret? This oyster I&#39;m about to eat could still be alive! So, why do we do this?&#34;</p><p>Most people think it&#39;s a food safety issue. Keep the oyster alive as long as possible, to reduce the risk of bacterial contamination. And there is a little bit of truth to that. Oysters can carry a scary flesh-eating bacteria called vibrio vulnificus. You can get it from oysters or from swimming in warm brackish water. But let&#39;s put that into perspective. </p><p><strong>Julie Qiu:</strong> &#34;The risk of running into a bad oyster is lower than people think it is. My biggest pet peeve is that people go crazy over one bad oyster but they don&#39;t really care that hundreds of thousands of pounds of lettuce are contaminated with salmonella&#34;</p><p>About <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/vibrio/index.html\">100 people die from vibrio infections</a> (including from vibrio vulnificus) each year, about <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/index.html\">450 die from salmonella. </a>Plus, the FDA requires that oyster farms have to test water quality before sending oysters out to markets and restaurants. And that&#39;s important, because oysters are filter feeders. They soak up basically anything that&#39;s in the water around them - including fecal matter which can come from rain runoff.</p><p>But there&#39;s a clever way to check if your oysters are good.</p><p><strong>Julie Qiu:</strong> &#34;one thing that you can ask for is a shellfish tag, which every retailer or restaurant is required to have for every bag of oysters that they purchase for up to 90 days after they make that purchase. So that tag, if they don&#39;t have it, don&#39;t eat those oysters.&#34;</p><p>This tag is a way for restaurants to track where and when their oysters were farmed. Qiu says that she looks<a href=\"https://www.santamonicaseafood.com/understanding-shellfish-tags\"> for the most recent dates</a> on the tag. Anything further out than two weeks won&#39;t taste as good and increases the risk of a bad oyster.</p><p>Some chefs may look at you funny for asking for the documentation, but it&#39;s a strategy that apparently works.</p><p><strong>Julie Qiu: </strong>&#34;I&#39;ve had thousands of oysters and never had a bad one&#34;</p><p>Ok great, so basically, oysters are safe, why on earth are they sometimes <em>alive </em>when we eat them??</p><p><strong>Julie Qiu: </strong>&#34;You really want your raw shellfish to be really fresh and the freshest you can get is something that is recently killed, so it goes back to not only the food safety but the actual taste and texture is going to be far superior when it&#39;s a fresh oyster.&#34; </p><p>So yeah, freshly killed oysters taste better. And it&#39;s hard to tell exactly when an oyster dies, because before it&#39;s served, it&#39;s shucked. It&#39;s not a gentle process. Shucking involves separating the oyster&#39;s abductor muscle from the shell. This muscle gives the oyster control over opening and closing its shell. Similar to how your spinal cord helps you move. So, severing the <em>their </em>abductor muscle is almost like severing <em>your</em> spine. Yikes.</p><p>Most restaurants in the US keep their oysters alive - on ice - up until this shucking process, which afterwards, either leaves the oyster dead, or immobile. Since they don&#39;t move around much in the first place, it&#39;s not easy to tell which.</p><p>So you&#39;re eating an oyster that was either just killed or is dying. And that seems pretty cruel, right? But considering that the oyster&#39;s biology is very primitive, it&#39;s possible they might not even feel pain at all.</p><p><strong>Julie Qiu: </strong>&#34;They don&#39;t have a brain, they&#39;re not really processing pain the same way the same way we are feeling so I don&#39;t think they&#39;re feeling pain the same way we are thinking of it.&#34;</p><p>So really, it&#39;s up to you. If you don&#39;t want to eat oysters, that&#39;s fine. If you do, you&#39;ll be far from the first.</p><p><strong>Julie Qiu: </strong>&#34;It&#39;s one of the few foods that have not changed for thousands and thousands of years so being able to appreciate that is something that&#39;s really special and remarkable and something that should be celebrated for what it is.&#34; </p><p><em>For more information about oysters from Qiu, check out her blog <a href=\"https://www.inahalfshell.com/\">In A Half Shell</a> or follow her on <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/inahalfshellblog/?hl=en\">Instagram</a>.</em></p><p><em>EDITOR&#39;S NOTE: This video was originally published in September 2018.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/oysters-still-alive-eaten-raw-vibrio-vulnificus-2018-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/G2iRB4kDHhU\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 30 Apr 2021 20:30:26 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5baa48bdea400291578b4567?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"fe1550ef3acbb0fee6f41cac18157ba0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn25@2020_1/2021/05/01/06-42-21-021_930fc62d199545cd.webp","destWidth":838,"destHeight":629,"sourceBytes":55794,"destBytes":55794,"author":"danderson@businessinsider.com (David Anderson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=G2iRB4kDHhU:826WImChiCY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn6@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-26-105_51847549fc9836b1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=G2iRB4kDHhU:826WImChiCY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn65@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-343_aa259991fddfe365.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=G2iRB4kDHhU:826WImChiCY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn94@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-24-891_b8f293b4a9c88075.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/G2iRB4kDHhU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn55@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-24-244_33e0f7cd4563d5ae.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324330},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"How a 26-year-old Harvard graduate and nonprofit cofounder spends his day","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/day-in-the-life-of-nonprofit-founder-activist-saad-amer-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608aecbf34af8d0018599f3d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Saad Amer Day in Life\" height=\"2634\" width=\"3513\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Saad Amer.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Saad Amer</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Saad Amer, 26, is the cofounder of the nonprofit <a href=\"https://www.plus1campaign.org/\">Plus1Vote</a>. </li>\n<li>The nonprofit seeks to help people vote in elections. </li>\n<li>He is also a fellow at Yale and works with the United Nations. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>No two days are the same for Saad Amer, the 26-year-old cofounder of <a href=\"https://www.plus1campaign.org/\">Plus1Vote</a>. Some days he&#39;s creating Instagram filters to educate people on the climate crisis; the next, he&#39;s helping send a million text messages to get young people to vote. Launched in 2018, his nonprofit seeks to improve voter turnout in national elections using social media to create campaigns and engage with young people.</p><p>The organization often partners with leaders like <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D6tPLKkdgcg\">Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez</a> and former Vice President Al Gore to host seminars educating people on climate change and voting rights. During the 2018 midterm elections, Plus1Vote launched a campaign that was supported and shared on social media by Alyssa Milano and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/jimmykimmel/status/1059541633845223424\">Jimmy Kimmel</a>. Plus1Vote also teamed up with the Women&#39;s March to help amplify the voices of people of color. </p><p>&#34;Our core mission is to improve the representation of young people and people of color in our democracy, especially on issues such as climate change and social justice,&#34; Amer told Insider. &#34;I recognized there was a gap in terms of the connection between these major issues and young people. I saw a need to energize young people, especially young people of color, to come into the voting space.&#34; </p><p>Plus1Vote partnered with V magazine during the 2020 election for the <a href=\"https://vmagazine.com/v-is-for-vote/\">V is for Vote issue</a>, which featured Mariah Carey and Taylor Swift. For January&#39;s runoff elections in Georgia, Plus1Vote teamed up with Uber to provide free rides to the polls and sent more than 1 million text messages to potential voters. </p><p>And that&#39;s just Amer&#39;s day job. He also works on the UN&#39;s Framework Convention on Climate Change&#39;s Youth Constituency, is an advisor to the National Parks Conservation Association, and is an expert reviewer for an intergovernmental panel on climate change report. </p><p>A graduate of Harvard, he cocreated the university&#39;s inaugural <a href=\"https://www.npca.org/people/saad-amer\">Sustainability Plan</a> and is a fellow at Yale University&#39;s Public Voices Fellowship on the Climate Crisis. For Insider, Amer revealed how he spends a typical day, which includes multiple chai latte breaks and speaking at virtual seminars on the climate crisis. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c400d35c46f0018c0ba7d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Saad Amer Day in Life\" height=\"2643\" width=\"3525\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Saad Amer.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Saad Amer</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>He wakes up at 8 a.m.</strong></h2><p>After waking up, Amer brushes his teeth, drinks a glass of water, and gets dressed. Early-morning tea time is at 8:30, which is a &#34;personal ceremony&#34; to him, allowing Amer to reflect on the day ahead and the day before. </p><p>&#34;Now that the weather is warmer, I&#39;ll have my first cup of tea outside in the morning,&#34; he said. &#34;I&#39;m not big on breakfast, but I&#39;ll usually have some kind of biscuit with my tea.&#34; Right now that means an Earl Grey in an &#34;overly fancy teapot&#34; with Dutch stroopwafel.</p><p>Amer has worked as an activist since the age of 13, when he began to do environmental work in his Long Island, New York, community, where he still lives today. In high school, he worked with the school&#39;s environmental organizations to help preserve land and went on to attend Harvard University, where he researched the impact of climate change on the Indian Himalayas with the United States Agency for International Development and helped discover a new <a href=\"https://bioone.org/journals/systematic-botany/volume-43/issue-2/036364418X697166/M[…]ae-a-New-Hybrid-Fern-from-French/10.1600/036364418X697166.short\">plant species</a> in French Polynesia. </p><p>He became heavily involved with voting after realizing many young people were not incentivized to vote, despite the way many issues like the climate emergency and social justice would be affecting them. &#34;It&#39;s all about young activists. It&#39;s about having our voice presenting and being able to elect policymakers,&#34; he said. &#34;That makes a grassroots effort more powerful.&#34; </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c3ff435c46f0018c0ba7c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Saad Amer Day in Life\" height=\"2643\" width=\"3525\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Amer&#39;s tea set.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Saad Amer</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>His first call with his team is at 9 a.m. </strong></h2><p>Amer takes his first morning call with the Plus1Vote team in which he discusses plans on how to organize and mobilize voters for upcoming elections. The team is focused on the &#34;<a href=\"https://www.commoncause.org/our-work/constitution-courts-and-democracy-issues/for-the-people-act/?gclid=Cj0KCQjwsqmEBhDiARIsANV8H3Yz-fOVYfaG0TDbfgzt1zsh0Xmx1ZA0J4mF-AJC9HWLT9ihfCDlWS8aAtwdEALw_wcBhttps://www.plus1campaign.org/forthepeople\">For the People</a>&#34; Act, or HR 1, which would expand voting rights. </p><p>Plus1Vote is planning social-media campaigns around the act and encouraging young people to write letters to their lawmakers to help push the bill through. &#34;Our democracy is at a crossroads,&#34; he said. &#34;The coup at the Capitol and the 360 voter-suppression bills across this country show how desperately we need to protect the right to vote.&#34; </p><p>In 2018, Plus1Vote made a video that highlighted the women of color who were running for public office across the country, including Ayanna Presley, who tweeted the video. &#34;Then, of course, she made history as the first Black woman elected to Congress from the state of Massachusetts,&#34; he said. </p><p>The organization depends heavily on the tools social media provides, such as Instagram filters, which help them further involve people in the spreading of social messages online. The celebrity endorsements, for the most part, are organic, he said. Much of Amer&#39;s time is spent conducting research and planning for events. &#34;Now that it&#39;s warmer I&#39;ll often work outside,&#34; Amer said.</p><h2><strong>Lunch is at noon</strong></h2><p>Today for lunch Amer is eating leftover Thai food, with some mango juice. &#34;There has been a rise in <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/we-are-not-monolith-danger-of-single-asian-american-story-2021-3\">hate crimes against the AAPI community</a> and Asian-owned businesses have been struggling through the pandemic,&#34; he said. </p><p>Amer recalls the day the insurrection at the Capitol happened. He was drinking a chai latte and couldn&#39;t believe what he was seeing on TV. But, if anything, it made him realize he has to work harder to get young people to vote and help elect lawmakers that better reflect their values. </p><p>&#34;I don&#39;t think it&#39;s the job of people of color to educate everybody on every single issue,&#34; he said. &#34;What we need is to see people brought to justice and for them to start educating themselves on the reality that we&#39;re in.&#34;  </p><h2><strong>Next, a speech for Earth Day </strong></h2><p>Last week the team was preparing for Earth Day. Amer said he made sure to read the announcements from the White House and Congress regarding the climate crisis in order to organize campaigns around it. </p><p>He also had to pay close attention to these statements because he is a member of the Youth Constituency to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. &#34;Staying plugged-in on the international developments of this week are crucial,&#34; he said. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608aec6735c46f0018c0b47e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Saad Amer Day in Life\" height=\"2852\" width=\"2036\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Amer and Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Saad Amer</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Amer has spoken at the UN &#34;like a bazillion times,&#34; he said, mostly &#34;yelling at various ministers and ambassadors about the need to really treat climate change as a major priority.&#34; Last year the organization was going to plan an Earth Day and climate strike, but it was canceled due to the pandemic. </p><p>They had to digitize the entire campaign, creating a three-day livestream in which Amer interviewed <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D6tPLKkdgcg\">Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez</a>. He had a similar virtual event this year with the same goal: making sure people understand being a climate activist is also being a voting activist. </p><p>&#34;Young people understand that we&#39;re seeing our futures being robbed from us,&#34; he said</p><p>&#34;There&#39;s a lot of gate-keeping in activism,&#34; he said. &#34;It&#39;s important to invite everybody into activism, especially into the voting space of our democracy, where everyone is supposed to be represented.&#34; </p><p>After lunch and a marathon Zoom call,  he takes a chai break around 3 p.m. &#34;I have multiple cups of chai per day and usually have one by my side while working and while on Zoom calls,&#34; he said. </p><h2><strong>Hosting rehearsal</strong></h2><p>At 5 p.m. he rushes to rehearsal for an event he&#39;s hosting on climate justice called Action for the Earth Symposium, which was later streamed on <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/NowthisEarth/posts/5585275784846889\">NowThis</a>. &#34;The event centers intersectional environmentalism and youth voices taking action on the climate crisis,&#34; he said. It also features the climate activist and writer Bill McKibben and Michigan Rep. Andy Levin.</p><p>A week earlier, he gave a guest lecture at the Harvard Graduate School for Education about youth civic engagement and spoke on a panel at Ohio State University on environmental justice.  And earlier this year, he hosted an event in which he spoke to the actor Mark Ruffalo, famed for his portrayal of Bruce Banner and the Hulk.</p><p>&#34;I was like, you&#39;re a climate activist - the Hulk is green because you are a climate activist, right?&#39;&#34; Amer joked and said Ruffalo confirmed, &#34;the Hulk is green because of climate change. &#34;</p><p>Aside from providing free Uber rides in Georgia, Plus1Vote also provided free rides to the polls during the presidential election in Florida, South Carolina, and Mississippi. &#34;It&#39;s really essential to use these different tools and platforms to give younger people access to the ballot,&#34; he said, adding the pandemic has only highlighted the issue more. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c405834af8d001859a4f1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Saad Amer\" height=\"2680\" width=\"3573\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Amer, center, at a climate-crisis march from September 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Saad Amer</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>Then he goes for an evening run </strong></h2><p>Around 6 p.m., after the bulk of his work is done and before the sun sets, he makes sure to catch some fresh air by going for a jog. </p><p>&#34;My favorite part about the spring is all the flower trees blooming,&#34; he said. &#34;I&#39;ll stop and smell the flowers every chance I get. I&#39;ll visit a few PokéStops,&#34; a reference to the mobile game &#34;Pokémon Go,&#34; &#34;and head home for dinner.&#34;</p><p>Dinner is typically at 7 p.m. and recently, he&#39;s been cooking aloo mutter, a potato and pea dish topped with fresh cilantro and served with methi paratha - a flatbread made with spices and fenugreek leaves. &#34;One of the best parts of South Asian cooking is the array of vegan options,&#34; he said. Amer is of South Asian descent. &#34;About a quarter of India is vegetarian, so there are plenty of options.&#34;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c409735c46f0018c0ba85?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Saad Amer Day in Life\" height=\"2643\" width=\"3525\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Saad Amer.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Saad Amer</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>Before bed, he writes </strong></h2><p>After dinner, he takes some time for writing as part of his Yale fellowship with The OpEd Project. &#34;I&#39;ve been working on a series of pieces on the climate crisis focused on environmental justice, civic engagement, and climate solutions,&#34; he said.</p><p>Afterward, he listens to music and audiobooks before retiring for the evening. He falls asleep, usually between 11 p.m. and 2 a.m., depending on the day. Then he wakes up and does it all over again.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/day-in-the-life-of-nonprofit-founder-activist-saad-amer-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a (Dominic-Madori Davis)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608aecbf34af8d0018599f3d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn10@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-07-793_32cb1766ba51aa2c.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c400d35c46f0018c0ba7d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn27@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-22-501_b6e07625859f554e.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c3ff435c46f0018c0ba7c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn89@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-26-044_3e339d445de74e81.webp","https://i.insider.com/608aec6735c46f0018c0b47e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn89@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-23-354_52f3e1a663aebdb7.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c405834af8d001859a4f1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn79@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-21-010_cd326d8f4da39fc5.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c409735c46f0018c0ba85?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn57@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-25-242_d0060c61e3784042.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=NS_wwEQLQSQ:3xAwzJJPWmE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn19@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-26-415_7ef572f4c060f5cd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=NS_wwEQLQSQ:3xAwzJJPWmE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn30@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-23-151_25556ba5a37e7e86.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=NS_wwEQLQSQ:3xAwzJJPWmE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn21@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-24-921_43b4ccadd4178588.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/NS_wwEQLQSQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn52@2020_1/2021/05/01/06-42-21-760_30df4baa8857d2c5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324347},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"Amazon was ranked by LinkedIn as the best place to grow your career. But the list omitted major factors like pay and race.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/linkedin-top-companies-career-growth-2021-list-omits-pay-race-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5b9ebfe6ff30001d4e8538?format=jpeg\" alt=\"LinkedIn office\" height=\"683\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>LinkedIn, which is owned by Microsoft, ranked Amazon as the best company for US workers to grow their careers in 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Rolf Vennenbernd/dpa/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Linkedin published its list of the <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/top-companies-2021-50-best-workplaces-grow-your-career-us-/?published=t\">top US companies</a> for career growth, ranking Amazon first.</li>\n<li>LinkedIn&#39;s revamped criteria this year included factors like promotion rates and gender diversity.</li>\n<li>But the list didn&#39;t consider other key factors like pay and racial diversity.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>In his <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-jeff-bezos-final-letter-to-shareholders-as-ceo-2021-4\">final letter to shareholders</a> as Amazon&#39;s CEO earlier this month, Jeff Bezos downplayed concerns about the company&#39;s working conditions, defending it as &#34;Earth&#39;s best employer and Earth&#39;s safest place to work.&#34;</p><p>The letter came on the heels of Amazon&#39;s aggressive <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/union-accuses-amazon-of-illegal-action-against-workers-familiar-playbook-2021-4\">anti-union campaign</a>, multiple <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nyt-labor-board-finds-amazon-illegally-fired-activist-employees-2021-4\">illegal firings</a> of whistleblowers, a tripling in the number of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/complaints-amazon-infringed-workers-union-rights-triples-nlrb-report-2021-3\">labor complaints</a> against the company last year, and climbing <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/explosive-reveal-amazon-warehouse-injuries-report-2020-9\">injury rates</a> that are nearly double the industry standard.</p><p>When Amazon announced its quarterly earnings call this week, it leaned on another source to prove that it&#39;s a great place to work: LinkedIn. On Wednesday, the Microsoft-owned job platform published a list ranking &#34;<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/top-companies-2021-50-best-workplaces-grow-your-career-us-/?published=t\">the 50 best workplaces to grow your career in the U.S.</a>&#34; in 2021.</p><p>According to LinkedIn&#39;s criteria, Amazon earned the top spot, which the company touted in its <a href=\"https://s2.q4cdn.com/299287126/files/doc_financials/2021/q1/Amazon-Q1-2021-Earnings-Release.pdf\">earnings release</a> along with high marks on lists by Fortune and Boston Consulting Group.</p><p>Amazon did not respond to a request for comment on this story.</p><p>LinkedIn did a massive overhaul of its criteria for this year&#39;s list - which it explained in depth in an accompanying <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/how-we-built-all-new-linkedin-top-companies-laura-lorenzetti/?trackingId=p1Mg7cA%2FRF%2BKKHSK0pIZiw%3D%3D\">blog post</a> - eventually landing on what it said were seven &#34;pillars&#34; that researchers have shown lead to career progression: &#34;ability to advance; skills growth; company stability; external opportunity; company affinity; gender diversity and educational background.&#34;</p><p>While any list claiming to rank the &#34;top&#34; anything is ultimately based on subjectively chosen criteria, several seemingly important factors didn&#39;t make the cut, including salary data or any demographic data beyond gender.</p><p>LinkedIn confirmed salaries were not factored into the rankings but wouldn&#39;t comment further about salaries on the record.</p><p>&#34;In terms of the diversity pillars, we measure gender diversity, specifically, which looks at gender parity within a company, as well as educational background, analyzing the spread of educational attainment among employees. We are working on additional diversity criteria and hope to continue expanding this pillar in future years,&#34; LinkedIn spokesperson Maggie Boezi told Insider in an email.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-employee-salary-pay-median-worker-compensation-compared-jeff-bezos-2021-4\">Amazon paid its median employee $29,007</a> last year, and the company said this week that it would <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-raise-pay-3-an-hour-for-500000-workers-2021-4\">raise pay by up to $3 per hour</a> for 500,000 employees. But despite lucrative salaries and benefits for <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cloud-salaries-revealed-what-amazon-microsoft-google-and-more-pay-2020-9#cloud-architects-at-amazon-web-services-can-make-around-150000-3\">corporate employees</a>, research has shown for years that Amazon setting up new warehouses often <a href=\"https://www.economist.com/united-states/2018/01/20/what-amazon-does-to-wages\">drives down wages in the area</a>.</p><p>Those salary disparities take on added significance when factoring in the <a href=\"https://www.aboutamazon.com/news/workplace/our-workforce-data\">racial disparities between Amazon&#39;s warehouse and corporate employees</a>. In 2020, 32.1% of all Amazon employees were white, while 13.6% were Asian, 26.5% were Black, 22.8% were Latinx, 3.6% were multiracial, and 1.5% were Native American.</p><p>But the path upward is narrow for employees of color at Amazon.</p><p>Among corporate employees, 47% are white, while 34.8% were Asian, 7.2% were Black, 7.5% were Latinx, 3% were multiracial, and 0.5% were Native American. Among senior leadership, 70.7% were white, 20% were Asian, 3.8% were Black, 3.9% were Latinx, 1.4% were multiracial, and 0.2% were Native American.</p><p>LinkedIn&#39;s decision to rank Amazon as the best place to grow your career without accounting for racial diversity data may be especially surprising to some members of Amazon&#39;s diversity and inclusion teams, who told Recode that internal Amazon data showed that <a href=\"https://www.vox.com/recode/2021/2/26/22297554/amazon-race-black-diversity-inclusion\">Black employees are promoted at a lower rate</a> and given worse performance reviews than white coworkers.</p><p>Insider&#39;s Allana Akhtar also reported that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/more-black-and-latino-senior-management-walmart-than-amazon-2021-4\">Amazon lags far behind competitors like Walmart</a> - ranked ninth on LinkedIn&#39;s list - when it comes to Black and Latino representation in upper management.</p><p>As for Amazon&#39;s warehouse workers, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2020-12-17/amazon-amzn-job-pay-rate-leaves-some-warehouse-employees-homeless\">Bloomberg</a> reported in December that Amazon is &#34;transforming the logistics industry from a career destination with the promise of middle-class wages into entry-level work that&#39;s just a notch above being a burger flipper or convenience store cashier,&#34; citing government data that showed more than 4,000 Amazon employees are on food stamps in just nine states.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.nelp.org/publication/amazons-disposable-workers-high-injury-turnover-rates-fulfillment-centers-california\">Turnover rates at Amazon warehouses are estimated to be as high as 100%</a>, according to the National Employment Law Project.</p><p>One possible explanation for why LinkedIn&#39;s list still ranked Amazon first despite the above data may be that its list appeared to focus on white-collar workers.</p><p>In her blog post explaining the methodology, LinkedIn senior managing editor Laura Lorenzetti, said that the list &#34;since its inception showed professionals where people like them were most eager to work.&#34;</p><p>Boezi, the LinkedIn spokesperson, told Insider that the list included all full-time and part-time employees regardless of job title - except freelancers and interns - and that LinkedIn &#34;regressed our findings against outside sources such as the World Bank and the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and evaluated various scoring mechanisms for every pillar we selected.&#34;</p><p>While LinkedIn&#39;s list may not single-handedly change jobseekers&#39; minds, Amazon&#39;s case reveals how the underlying data that goes into such rankings is far from unbiased.<a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/vickyvalet/2019/11/21/linkedin-for-the-working-class-how-jobcase-is-building-a-1-billion-social-network-for-blue-collar-employees/?sh=322db4c72105\"></a></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/linkedin-top-companies-career-growth-2021-list-omits-pay-race-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=2aBPy2BVF3M:G1F_SvqNX0U:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2aBPy2BVF3M:G1F_SvqNX0U:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=2aBPy2BVF3M:G1F_SvqNX0U:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2aBPy2BVF3M:G1F_SvqNX0U:V_sGLiPBpWU\" data-type=\"h2\">Table of Contents: Masthead Sticky</bi-shortcode><p> </p><p>Though vaccine rollouts are well underway, travelers continue to turn to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/safe-vacations-during-covid\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">safer vacation options</a> from <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/uncrowded-summer-beach-vacations\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">less crowded beaches</a> to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-road-trips-us\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">road trips</a>. Recreational Vehicles, commonly known as RVs or motor homes, are especially ideal for social distancing and offer more flexibility while on the road.</p><p>Self-contained, self-sufficient, versatile, and equipped to travel across the entire continent, they make an attractive proposition. Travelers can eat, sleep, wash, and drive themselves all in one collective environment without encountering anyone else, plus travelers aren&#39;t tied to specific destinations and bypass the need to pay for pricey hotels or vacation rentals.</p><p>RV and motor home rental companies have seen a major uptick in the past year, a trend that looks to continue.</p><p>&#34;Renting an RV is a lot easier than most people think,&#34; says Maddie Bourgerie, spokesperson for Akron-based, peer-to-peer rental company <a href=\"https://go.redirectingat.com/?id=35871X943606&url=https%3A%2F%2Frvshare.com%2Fm%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">RVShare</a>. &#34;Similar to most vehicle rentals, you need a valid driver&#39;s license and be over the age of 25.&#34;</p><p>RV rental companies break down into two main categories, corporate and peer-to-peer. If you&#39;re renting an RV for the first time and are not sure where to start, jump to the bottom of this guide for <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-rv-rentals#popular-types-of-rvs-and-motor-homes-5\">tips and more information on types of RVs</a>.</p><h2>The best RV rental companies</h2><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-rv-rentals/#outdoorsy-1\">Outdoorsy</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-rv-rentals/#rv-share-2\">RV Share</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-rv-rentals/#cruise-america-3\">Cruise America</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-rv-rentals/#el-monte-rv-4\">El Monte RV</a></li></ul>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tOutdoorsy\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ecd337d988ee3225a036ce4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Outdoorsy\" height=\"472\" width=\"472\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Outdoorsy</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Pros</strong>: An extensive network and vehicle search options include 'pet-friendly' and 'festival-ready.' Vehicle owners may even deliver vehicles to campgrounds so that renters just show up and enjoy the accommodations instead of driving them.</p><p><strong>Cons</strong>: Customers are dealing with individual renters, who have different policies about mileage charges and costs to drop off vehicles.</p><p><strong>Company info:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.outdoorsy.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Outdoorsy</a> is a peer-to-peer RV rental company based in Austin, Texas. The company has over 40,000 vehicles listed and operates out of 4,800 cities across 14 countries. The company has great feedback, and although not accredited by them, it has an A+ rating from the Better Business Bureau (BBB).</p><p><strong>Typical rental costs: </strong></p><p><strong>Class A motor coach, sleeping up to 6 people - 2,000 miles free, $0.35 for every mile over per day, $240 per night.</strong> Middle of the range vehicle, fully equipped kitchen (stove, fridge, microwave), shower, and toilet, TV and CD player.&#160;</p><p><strong>Class B Mercedes, sleeping two people - 150 miles free per trip, $0.25 for every mile over, $339 per night.</strong> Top of the range luxury vehicle, fully equipped dining and entertainment amenities, shower and toilet, dining room.&#160;</p><p><strong>Class C Winnebago, sleeping 4-6 people - 100 miles free per day, $0.35 for every mile over per day, $192 per night.</strong> Fully equipped kitchen, shower and toilet, TV and CD player.&#160;</p><p>Cancellation policies depend on individual owners.</p><p>COVID-19 policies can be found <a href=\"https://www.outdoorsy.com/help/question-covid-19\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">here</a>.&#160;</p><h2><a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.outdoorsy.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Book an RV rental through Outdoorsy</a></h2>\n\tRV Share\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ec81d792618b903d83aa8a4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RV Share\" height=\"1200\" width=\"1600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">RV Share</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Pros</strong>: They offer pet-friendly options and can arrange to have their drivers deliver to the renters' preferred locations (please note these delivery options do incur additional fees). The company was the first peer-to-peer option for RV rentals.</p><p><strong>Cons</strong>: Customers deal with individual renters who have different policies about mileage charges, cancellation, and costs to drop off vehicles.&#160;</p><p><strong>Company info</strong>: RVShare is one of two of the bigger peer-to-peer RV rental companies in the United States, reporting a community of around 60,000 RV owners across the country. The company is also not BBB accredited, but also an A+ rating from the organization.</p><p><strong>Typical rental costs:&#160;</strong></p><p><strong>Class A Fleetwood Bounder motor home, sleeping up to 9 people - 150 miles free per trip, $0.25 for every mile over, $245 per night.</strong> Luxury vehicle, fully equipped dining and entertainment amenities, shower, and toilet.&#160;</p><p><strong>Class B Chinook, sleeping two people - 150 miles free per trip, $0.45 for every mile over, $175 per night</strong>. Middle-of-the-range vehicle, fully equipped dining and entertainment amenities, shower and toilet, dining room.&#160;</p><p><strong>Class C Classic Freelander motor home, sleeps up to 8 people - 200 miles free per trip, $0.50 for every mile over, $268 per night.</strong> Middle of the range vehicle, fully equipped dining and entertainment amenities, shower and toilet.&#160;</p><p>Cancellation policies depend on individual owners.&#160;</p><p>COVID-19 policies can be found <a href=\"https://rvshare.com/blog/coronavirus-rvs-what-you-need-to-know/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">here</a>.</p><h2><strong><a href=\"https://go.redirectingat.com/?id=35871X943606&#38;url=https%3A%2F%2Frvshare.com%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Book an RV through RVshare.com</a></strong></h2>\n\tCruise America\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ec81f551918247626506947?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Cruise America\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Cruise America</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Pros</strong>: The company offers customers an attractive range of extra packages such as blankets and towels or camping supply kits. The website regularly has special offers including free nights and one-way specials.</p><p><strong>Cons</strong>: No standard free mileage, so long trips can rack up the costs.&#160;</p><p><strong>Company info</strong>: An employee-owned company based in Mesa, AZ, <a href=\"https://www.cruiseamerica.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Cruise America</a> has operated since 1972. It now boasts 132 locations across the United States and Canada. The company is not accredited by the BBB, but they do receive an A rating.&#160;</p><p><strong>Typical rental costs</strong>:</p><p><strong>Class A large Ford motor home, sleeping up to 7 people -$170 per night.</strong> Mid-range vehicle, fully equipped dining and entertainment amenities, shower and toilet.&#160;&#160;</p><p><strong>Class B standard motor home, sleeping up to 5 people - $160 per night.</strong> Mid-range vehicle, fully equipped dining and entertainment amenities, shower and toilet.&#160;</p><p><strong>Class C compact motor home, sleeping up to 3 people - $150 per night.</strong> Mid-range vehicle, fully equipped dining and entertainment amenities, shower and toilet.&#160;</p><p>An estimated mileage charge applies to all rentals. The charge will be a per night charge based on 100 miles for local rentals and 250 miles for a one-way rental. The rate is $0.35 per mile for all vehicles and cancellations are currently being assessed on a case-by-case basis.</p><p>COVID-19 policies can be found <a href=\"https://www.cruiseamerica.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">here</a>.</p><h2><a href=\"https://www.cruiseamerica.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Book an RV through Cruise America</a></h2>\n\tEl Monte RV\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ec820043ad8617f6b3e94f6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"El Monte RV\" height=\"1066\" width=\"1421\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">El Monte RV</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Pros</strong>: A long time rental provider, the company offers many specials on their websites ranging from free mileage to free nights, with good one-way deals, too.&#160;</p><p><strong>Cons</strong>: There is no standard free mileage, so long trips can rack up costs. Customer satisfaction varies across locations, so be sure to research specific ones depending on your trip's geographical requirements. Reservations might be paused or restricted in states with high COVID-19 infection rates.</p><p><strong>Company info</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.elmonterv.com/Default.aspx?tabid=55&#38;error=An%20unexpected%20error%20has%20occurred&#38;content=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">El Monte</a> has been operational for over 40 years, though its network is smaller in scope than Cruise America. The company has 13 locations that are well-dispersed around the country and cover 12 states (with two locations in Florida).</p><p><strong>Typical rental costs</strong>:</p><p><strong>Class A large family motor home, sleeping up to 6 people - $338 per night.</strong> Mid-range vehicle, fully equipped dining and entertainment amenities, shower and toilet.&#160;</p><p><strong>Class B standard motor home, sleeping up to 5 people - $225 per night.</strong> Mid-range vehicle, fully equipped dining and entertainment amenities, shower and toilet.</p><p><strong>Class C compact motor home, sleeping up to 4 people - $145 per night.</strong> Mid-range vehicle, fully equipped dining and entertainment amenities, shower and toilet.&#160;</p><p>The mileage charge is $0.32-$0.39 per mile depending on unit size or prepaid in blocks of 100 miles for $29 each. For cancellations, the renter's credit card is charged $250 deposit to reserve an RV. Renters may cancel within 24 hours and receive a refund of the deposit. The deposit is non-refundable 24 hours after booking. Unlike others on this list, these quotes are for vehicle pick up in Miami, and all vehicles are 2018 models or newer.&#160;</p><p>COVID-19 policies can be found <a href=\"https://www.elmonterv.com/travel-advisory-covid-19\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">here</a>.</p><h2><a href=\"https://www.elmonterv.com/Default.aspx?tabid=55&#38;error=An%20unexpected%20error%20has%20occurred&#38;content=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Book an RV from El Monte</a></h2>\n\tHow we chose the best RV rentals\n\t\n\t<p>We considered key factors, including:</p><p><strong>Variety:</strong> From large Class A RVs to two-person Class B RVs to luxury options with extras (more on class types below), we considered how much variety rental companies offered and how many vehicles they have as part of their fleet.&#160;&#160;</p><p><strong>Price:&#160;</strong>The average price of rentals played a big part in our choice. All sample quotes listed below are for a 45-year old driver for a two-week trip, booking two months in advance, picking up the vehicle at the point of rental, and starting from and returning to New Orleans. Different models will incur different fuel costs depending on their size, the terrain, and whether they are gas or diesel engines.</p><p><strong>Inclusions</strong>:&#160;All rentals listed in our guide come with generators, are covered by the company's own insurance policies, and offer some kind of loyalty rewards program.</p><p><strong>COVID-19 procedures: </strong>They all offer robust cleaning policies in response to COVID-19 so you can feel at ease.</p><p>&#160;</p>\n\tPopular types of RVs and motor homes\n\t\n\t<p>There are different classes of RVs and motor homes, each with pros and cons, so it is best to decide which one best suits your plans before booking.&#160;&#160;</p><h3>Class A motor homes</h3><p>Class A motor homes are the largest and can sleep up to 10 people on the bigger side (up to 45 feet or so in length). They are, essentially, houses on wheels, usually part of a truck or bus chassis.</p><p>They tend to have the most luxurious amenities, often with master bedrooms and full kitchens with fridges, microwaves, and electrical or gas stovetops, as well as living rooms, dining rooms, and large bathrooms. They're ideal for large families or those looking for an experience similar to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-glamping-us\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">glamping</a>, more akin to staying in a hotel.</p><p>They are also typically the most expensive to rent and less fuel-efficient, usually only managing eight to 10 miles to the gallon. Bigger models can also find problems fitting into some smaller campsites, which can limit overnight options on the road. The large size also means these vehicles are best-suited to seasoned, experienced RV users and drivers. First-timers should probably try smaller models first to gain a feel for traveling this way.</p><h3>Class B motor homes</h3><p>Class B motor homes are the smallest category and are usually a good fit for two people, though even then they can feel somewhat cramped. The larger ones will have comfortable sleeping quarters but small kitchens and work well for those traveling in minimal style or on shorter vacations.</p><p>This class of RV is generally much more affordable with better fuel economy, delivering up to 25 miles per gallon. They also slip neatly into almost every campground.</p><p>However, expect limited amenities and storage space, and often with a 'wet bath' set up, meaning that the toilet and shower share the same space.</p><h3>Class C motor homes</h3><p>Class C motor homes are somewhere in between these two first categories. They are usually built onto a truck chassis with an overhang that fits over the driving cab, which is usually, but not always, used for sleeping space.</p><p>They sleep anywhere from two up to eight people at the large end, and most have toilet and shower facilities on board.</p><p>They come with better pricing, fuel economy (they typically manage up to 13 miles per gallon), and the ability to enter most campgrounds compared to Class A motor homes, however, they are not as efficient as Class B motor homes when it comes to parking, size, and fuel efficiency. They are usually acceptable for a short vacation, but not generally suggested as vehicles for extended trips.</p>\n\tImportant information and tips for first-time RV renters\n\t\n\t<p>First-time RV drivers should take time to familiarize themselves with the vehicle. \"There's no special training or license needed to drive an RV,\" says Jeff Cavins of fellow peer-to-peer rental company <a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.outdoorsy.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow sponsored\">Outdoorsy</a>, based in Austin. \"However, our owners will do a test drive with you before you leave on your trip to make sure you feel really comfortable with the vehicle, how it drives and how all the features work.\"</p><p>For the trip itself, forward planning is key, especially as states begin to reopen to varying degrees. \"Research where you want to go before you depart,\" says Cavins. \"Each day, we're monitoring the news of campgrounds reopenings taking place in each state and updating our list of state park systems and their status.\" Cavins recommends checking websites such as <a href=\"http://www.harvesthosts.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Harvest Hosts</a>&#160;and <a href=\"http://www.campendium.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Campendium</a> to book suitable rest locations.&#160;</p><p>Check first that you may park your specific vehicle at your intended campground, as well as the facilities they provide. Booking ahead is especially crucial with the increased demand.</p><p>Overnight campsite and RV parks come with hookup fees to provide electricity, water, bathrooms, and/or sewage disposal, and typically range from $30 to $50 per night or more for the best quality grounds.</p><p>It's also possible to find places to park (usually for limited amounts of time) without any facilities, either in remote areas or at designated spots. This is called 'dry camping' or 'boondocking' and is usually free of charge. You can find these locations on the website for the <a href=\"http://www.www.fs.usda.gov\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">United States Forest Service</a> or <a href=\"https://www.campendium.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Campendium</a>.</p><p>Additionally, don't hit the road without a full complement of groceries and other essentials on board as it may be tricky to stop at some of the smaller, rural communities that drivers will likely pass through, especially for larger vehicles.&#160;</p>\n\tMore
