Oswell)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ec81faa988ee307151e8404?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-05-611_a3303df343d81643.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ecd337d988ee3225a036ce4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn31@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-22-837_a11c9582ef5406e0.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ec81d792618b903d83aa8a4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn1@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-25-510_dcc62bea40a50b0e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ec81f551918247626506947?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn81@2020_4/2021/05/01/06-42-23-314_0690559eff87e549.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ec820043ad8617f6b3e94f6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn77@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-25-025_b21b2d0524755483.webp","https://i.insider.com/600efafb4827e700188a12cf?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn35@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-23-514_09d024776295c7c7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=huGrpQ4Qf8I:-0J2OBEKeJU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn15@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-26-325_f6f177b5e12d9c86.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=huGrpQ4Qf8I:-0J2OBEKeJU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn20@2020_1/2021/05/01/06-42-22-045_785825a76984a3ee.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=huGrpQ4Qf8I:-0J2OBEKeJU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn4@2020_5/2021/05/01/06-42-22-372_843edefa35658f2d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/huGrpQ4Qf8I":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn95@2020_1/2021/05/01/06-42-22-818_b1478964a6384c62.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324341},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"People - not process - are the drivers of transformation, according to business leaders from Microsoft and Accenture","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/people-not-process-or-technology-are-the-true-drivers-of-transformation-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608aabf835c46f0018c0b327?format=jpeg\" alt=\"HIBT 2 image\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/companies-diversity-equity-inclusion-embedding-into-culture-2020-12\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\"></a>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Business transformation has been perceived as a top-down process driven by technology and process.</li>\n<li>Leaders increasingly understand that developing people and culture are the true catalysts for innovation. </li>\n<li>Managers have to be incentivized to embody the culture in order for it to become part of the operation.</li>\n<li><a style=\"font-family: Georgia, Times, sans-serif;\" href=\"https://www.insider.com/human-impact-of-business-transformation\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\">This article is part of an ongoing series on Insider&#39;s research on The Human Impact of Business Transformation. </a></li>\n</ul><p>Historically, business transformation has been a top-down endeavor largely focused on technology, process, and operations. As savvy leaders know, there&#39;s another essential component to successful reinvention: People. By empowering their employees to be catalysts for change, and inviting them to help reshape their organizations from the bottom up, today&#39;s business leaders are finding that culture and purpose are key. </p><p>As head of global employee, leader &#38; culture communications at Microsoft, Letty Cherry&#39;s primary goal is to keep employees informed, engaged, and proud of their association with the company. With Microsoft currently employing more than 160,000 people worldwide, this is a significant task. Cherry and her team have managed to increase engagement and invite outside perspective via activities like employee town halls, company hackathons, and &#34;Outside in,&#34; a cross-company learning event wherein business leaders on book tours stop by the company to talk business philosophy, creativity, mindfulness, and more.</p><p>Reaching this point required that Microsoft get a drum beat on its mission.&#34;The mission of the company is everywhere,&#34; Cherry says. &#34;It&#39;s printed on our employee badges. We talk about it a lot in terms of empowering every person and every organization on the planet. But the culture needs to ladder up to it.&#34; </p><p>Company culture needs to evolve over time as you see gaps or as circumstances change, Cherry explains. As such, a central team monitors Microsoft&#39;s cultural attributes, ensures employees are familiar with them, and makes sure leaders are exhibiting them. Microsoft prioritizes diversity and inclusion, and works to teach its people how they can be &#34;good allies to each other,&#34; Cherry says. Providing employees with channels for different topics of conversation is critical, too, even if they don&#39;t always agree with each other.</p><p>Abiding by the company&#39;s values, which include respect, integrity, and accountability, helps employees in a number of ways; it creates a sense of security so they can be free to maximize their potential, but it also &#34;clears away the clutter&#34; so they can innovate. But Cherry notes that in order for companies to effectively convey these rules, their managers must learn to embrace them.&#34;</p><h3>Making culture and purpose real</h3><p>You can roll out whatever you want on culture. If the manager of your individual team isn&#39;t living by that culture, it causes problems,&#34; she says. Her advice to business leaders unsure of how to activate their workforce? &#34;Check your bias at the door.&#34; Empathy, vulnerability, and promoting two-way dialogue are all critical to removing barriers so you can develop both your talent and your brand. </p><p>At Accenture, Amy Fuller, chief marketing and communications officer, takes a similar approach. She manages everything from how the company markets to how it communicates to its talent brand, but the latter is increasingly important. As Fuller puts it, &#34;For anything to work at a professional services company, it really needs to work with the people because they are the brand.&#34; </p><p>There&#39;s a lot of focus on the concept of purpose at Accenture, which Fuller calls &#34;the topic of the moment.&#34; For purpose to endure, she says, it has to embody the value of your business: who you are, and what you do. </p><p>&#34;In the past couple of years, purpose has almost become a marketing cliché,&#34; Fuller says, adding that &#34;The value of a cliché is that everyone hears about it.&#34; Still, when the company surveyed its workforce of 500,000 global employees to find out how they defined Accenture&#39;s purpose, not everyone was on the same page.  Some employees were unable to communicate it, while others defaulted to citing the company&#39;s advertising tagline. &#34;It was an open door for us to articulate something that was important,&#34; Fuller says.</p><h3>&#34;Technology plus people&#34;</h3><p>Naturally, being purposeful as a business requires the help of your employees. &#34;What we hear from our clients is that it&#39;s all about people and technology. Not just one of those components - it&#39;s actually both,&#34; Fuller says. &#34;That is the moment we&#39;re in, in the world. It&#39;s technology, plus people, and how they coexist.&#34;</p><p>As Fuller notes, one thing many CEOs concern themselves with when it comes to their people is assessing how they collaborate. &#34;How our people operate is actually the core of Accenture,&#34; Fuller says. &#34;[They] are not simply those who work at Accenture; they are literally the product and our distribution channel, all at once.&#34;</p><p>In theory, that should make the task of empowering Accenture&#39;s people to help grow the company feel monumental, but Fuller has cracked the code. It&#39;s all about living those coveted values from the inside-out. </p><p>&#34;For our purpose to become real,&#34; Fuller says, &#34;the number one thing is that it cannot just be words. When we&#39;ve done additional research to ask people, clients, and our talent what would make this notion real, (the answer is), &#34;I need to see it in my daily life. I need to see my leaders actually be using it to guide decisions. It needs to be extremely relevant.&#34;</p><p>Encouraging your leaders to embody your company&#39;s culture and demonstrate the optimal mindset, while also giving people - your most valuable asset - a voice, can transform businesses for the better. As Cherry puts it, &#34;We look at our employees as a force for change.&#34;</p><p> </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/people-not-process-or-technology-are-the-true-drivers-of-transformation-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/OQ9zcY7sgpU\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 30 Apr 2021 19:58:26 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608aabf835c46f0018c0b327?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"e4954c98977e46c51f46e0621fd53cbe","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn13@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-16-579_6383a73637cb8965.webp","destWidth":1200,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":32246,"destBytes":32246,"author":"insider@insider.com (Jenifer Berman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608aabf835c46f0018c0b327?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn13@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-16-579_6383a73637cb8965.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn14@2020_3/2021/05/01/06-42-25-622_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OQ9zcY7sgpU:nwwF_bair8Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn38@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-190_caee6c20a73756ba.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OQ9zcY7sgpU:nwwF_bair8Q:V_sGLiPBpWU":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-23-338_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=OQ9zcY7sgpU:nwwF_bair8Q:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn85@2020_6/2021/05/01/06-42-24-786_6e87f2b5246d62df.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/OQ9zcY7sgpU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn66@2020_2/2021/05/01/06-42-24-944_c4286d3509d3c66e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619851324314},{"createdTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"NASA's Mars helicopter shattered previous records in its fourth aerial adventure","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-mars-ingenuity-helicopter-broke-records-fourth-flight-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/607ce7a044f454001920757d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ingenuity mars helicopter pre flight thumb 2x1\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Left: Ingenuity on the surface of Mars. Right: An illustration of Ingenuity flying.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA/JPL-Caltech/ASU</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-flies-on-mars-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"fd394b7e6cfa4c6eafc0c12aec199a05\">NASA&#39;s Ingenuity helicopter</a> successfully executed a fourth flight over Mars on Friday. </li>\n<li>The excursion took the helicopter farther and faster than the prior three.</li>\n<li>NASA engineers have given Ingenuity a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-mars-helicopter-to-start-scouting-2021-4\">surprise second mission to scout new Martian territory</a>.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-flies-on-mars-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"fd394b7e6cfa4c6eafc0c12aec199a05\">NASA&#39;s Mars helicopter</a> keeps exceeding expectations: Ingenuity completed its fourth flight on Friday, traveling farther over the Martian surface than on any of its previous journeys.</p><p>NASA engineers were <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-team-push-mars-ingenuity-helicopter-until-crashes-2021-4\">prepared for the 4-pound helicopter to crash</a>, since they&#39;re pushing it to new limits with each flight. But in this case, the tiny rotorcraft soared above rocks, sand ripples, and small craters at record speed.</p><p>NASA hasn&#39;t released details of the flight yet, but the plan called for Ingenuity to climb 16 feet in the air and reach a maximum speed of 3.5 meters per second - a feat NASA engineers weren&#39;t certain it could achieve.</p><p>The helicopter has thus far proven so successful that NASA announced on Friday it will <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-mars-helicopter-to-start-scouting-2021-4\">give Ingenuity an extended mission</a>. The original plan was to abandon the helicopter after its fifth flight. But now, NASA engineers plan to turn Ingenuity&#39;s photos into a 3D map of the uncharted terrain it covered on Friday. From that data, they&#39;ll pick a new airfield where the drone will try to land during its fifth flight, in about a week.</p><p>Once in that new airfield, Ingenuity is set to spend 30 more days testing out operations that NASA might want to conduct with future space helicopters. That includes scouting and mapping, observing interesting features of Mars from the air, and exploring rough terrain that rovers can&#39;t access.</p><p>&#34;The ability to fly the helicopter out into terrain that the rover cannot possibly traverse and bring back scientific data - this is extremely important for future missions that could combine a rover with a reconnaissance helicopter,&#34; Perseverance scientist Ken Farley said in a briefing on Friday.</p><h2>Ingenuity&#39;s 4th flight</h2><p>The first attempt at Friday&#39;s aerial adventure didn&#39;t succeed. The flight was originally scheduled for Thursday, but a non-damaging software glitch <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-failed-lift-off-ambitious-fourth-flight-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"d2dff729e40375c6e01558156820428d\">prevented the helicopter from lifting off</a>. NASA engineers expect that outcome in 15% of flight attempts.</p><p>If Ingenuity&#39;s Friday flight went as planned, it should have lifted off at 10:46 a.m. ET and flown for 117 seconds. Ingenuity was programmed to traveled south for around 436 feet, snapping photos of the Martian surface along the way. At that point, it was expected to hover and take images with its color camera, then turn around and land in its original spot.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608af7e235c46f0018c0b4be?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ingenuity helicopter mars fourth flight perseverance rover\" height=\"856\" width=\"1141\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Perseverance rover snapped this photo of Ingenuity on the Martian surface after its fourth flight on April 29, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://mars.nasa.gov/mars2020/multimedia/raw-images/ZL0_0068_0672980800_937ECM_N0032208ZCAM05054_110085J\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/JPL-Caltech/ASU</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In Ingenuity&#39;s first flight on April 19, the helicopter <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-flies-on-mars-2021-4\">made history</a> by rising 10 feet above Mars&#39; surface. Never before had a spacecraft conducted a controlled, powered flight on another planet. Then on April 22, Ingenuity reached an altitude of 16 feet and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-second-mars-flight-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"4f18aa4617067ce02c3d6773b29764f7\">moved sideways</a> for the first time.</p><p>On Sunday, the helicopter <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-third-mars-flight-2021-4\">traveled</a> 50 meters (164 feet) - nearly half the length of a football field. It also moved faster than before, increasing its airspeed to 2 meters per second, or around 4.5 miles per hour. Until that flight, Ingenuity had never flown so quickly, even during testing on Earth. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f2110e040c1f316e20b1493?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mars helicopter ingenuity nasa gif\" height=\"360\" width=\"640\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An animation of NASA&#39;s Ingenuity helicopter exploring the Martian surface.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://mars.nasa.gov/resources/24935/nasa-mars-helicopter-ingenuity-animations/\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/JPL-Caltech</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Friday&#39;s flight was the helicopter&#39;s most daring yet, but things are about to get even riskier.</p><h2>Ingenuity and Perseverance are starting new mission phases</h2><p>Once Ingenuity reaches its new airfield, the Perseverance rover - which carried the helicopter to Mars - is set to move on to its main mission on the red planet: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-mars-rover-landing-jezero-crater-search-for-alien-life-2021-2\">hunting for fossils of ancient alien microbes</a>. It aims to take dozens of rock samples and store them for a future spacecraft to retrieve and bring back to Earth. Those would be the first samples humanity has ever brought home from Mars.</p><p>Ingenuity&#39;s next flights, meanwhile, will gather data on new terrain that&#39;s too dangerous for the rover.</p><p>&#34;In doing these operational scenarios, we will naturally be pushing the limits of Ingenuity,&#34; MiMi Aung, project manager for Ingenuity, said in the Friday briefing. &#34;We hope we will be flying over unsurveyed terrains and, over time, continuing to transfer to airfields that are not well characterized. So there is a higher probability of bad landing.&#34;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/607d633944f4540019207601?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ingenuity helicopter first photo shadow flight mars\" height=\"1001\" width=\"1333\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ingenuity snapped this photo of its shadow on the ground below as it flew on Mars for the first time, April 19, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Aung has previously said that a bad landing would end Ingenuity&#39;s flights.</p><h2>Flying on Mars isn&#39;t easy</h2><p>For Ingenuity to fly at all, several factors have to go just right. The helicopter flies autonomously, using its cameras to track surface features on Mars in order to navigate. So there can&#39;t be too much dust on its camera lenses, since that could interfere with the navigation. </p><p>Speeding up challenges the chopper&#39;s mechanics and navigation system as well.</p><p>&#34;We navigate by taking images of the ground below,&#34; Håvard Grip, Ingenuity&#39;s chief pilot, said in a recent briefing. &#34;And as we&#39;re traveling faster over the ground, the features in those images disappear from you faster.&#34;</p><p>During test flights, NASA engineers were able to prevent crashes by pressing an emergency land button. But on Mars, they can&#39;t exert that kind of control.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/606b3ae0a7d803001963ebe2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mars ingenuity helicopter nasa perseverance rover\" height=\"960\" width=\"1280\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ingenuity on Mars, sitting where the Perseverance rover dropped it on April 5, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://mars.nasa.gov/mars2020/multimedia/raw-images/NLF_0044_0670852159_569ECM_N0031416NCAM03044_01_295J\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/JPL-Caltech</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Whatever happens after this, NASA engineers already consider Ingenuity&#39;s mission a success.</p><p>&#34;If Ingenuity would have crashed after the first flight, we still would have met a couple huge milestones including surviving launch, charging while en route, and surviving the entry, descent, and landing,&#34; Shannah Withrow-Maser, Ingenuity&#39;s vehicle systems lead, <a href=\"https://www.reddit.com/r/space/comments/mz4duo/were_nasa_experts_working_on_the_marshelicopter/\">recently wrote on Reddit</a>.</p><p>&#34;Deploying from the rover and surviving the cold Martian night are no small tasks,&#34; she added. &#34;If the flight wouldn&#39;t have been successful, we would have a lot of data and lessons learned. Think of everything else as bonus!&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-mars-ingenuity-helicopter-broke-records-fourth-flight-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 14:42:04","updatedTime":"2021-05-01 14:42:04","title":"Self-driving truck startup Plus is reportedly seeking to raise up to $600 million via a SPAC merger with Hennessy Capital Investment Corp V","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/self-driving-truck-startup-plus-raise-600-million-spac-merger-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608bfd0734af8d001859a190?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Plus_autonomous_truck_powered_by_PlusDrive 16\" height=\"1499\" width=\"2999\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Plus autonomous truck example.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://plus.ai/in-the-news.html\" target=\"_blank\">Plus</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Self-driving truck startup Plus is set to merge with the SPAC Hennessy Capital Investment Corp. V.</li>\n<li>Plus is hoping to raise up to $600 million in the deal which values the combined entity at over $3 billion.</li>\n<li>Plus was founded in 2016 by Stanford Ph.D. candidates and has raised $520 million over the last five years.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/10-things-opening-bell?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestedium=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Sign up here for our daily newsletter, 10 Things Before the Opening Bell</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A self-driving truck startup called <a href=\"https://plus.ai/index.html\">Plus</a> is seeking to raise up to $600 million in a merger with the special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) Hennessy Capital Investment Corp. V, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-30/self-driving-truck-startup-plus-said-to-plan-hennessy-spac-deal\">Bloomberg reported on Friday</a>.</p><p>The deal could go through as soon as next week, and the combined entity is set to have a valuation of over $3 billion, people familiar with the matter said.</p><p>BlackRock, already an investor in Hennessey, is looking to put additional funds into the self-driving truck startup through a private investment in public equity (PIPE) as well, Bloomberg reported.</p><p>The Hennessy V SPAC raised <a href=\"https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2021/01/21/2162091/0/en/Hennessy-Capital-Investment-Corp-V-Announces-the-Appointment-of-Independent-Directors-and-the-Formation-of-a-Strategic-Advisory-Council.html\">$345 million</a> in a January IPO and has been looking for a partner ever since. It trades on the NASDAQ under the ticker &#34;HCICU.&#34;</p><p>Hennessy V is chief executive Daniel J. Hennessy&#39;s fifth special purpose investment vehicle.</p><p>The CEO has raised more than $1.5 billion from SPAC IPOs thus far, completing deals with an electric vehicle company called <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/goev-stock\">Canoo</a>, a school bus manufacturer called <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/blbd-stock\">Blue Bird Corp.</a>, and a transportation and logistics company called <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/dske-stock\">Daseke</a>.</p><p>Now Hennessy is looking to link up with Cupertino, California-based Plus which was founded by a group of Stanford Ph.D. candidates including David Liu, Hao Zheng, and Shawn Kerrigan in June of 2016.</p><p>The self-driving truck company has raised $520 million from investors like Sequoia China, SAIC Capital, and Quanta Computer over the last five years, according to <a href=\"https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/plusai/company_financials\">data from Crunchbase.</a></p><p>Plus focuses on using AI technology to enable large-scale autonomous commercial trucking fleets. It currently boasts some of the only fully functional Level-4 autonomous trucks on the market.</p><p>Bloomberg reported Plus recently hired Dennis Mooney from Navistar and Chuck Joseph from Amazon to help scale production and promote the adoption of the company&#39;s tech.</p><p>Plus also has a partnership with the European truckmaker Iveco SpA and is <a href=\"https://plus.ai/press-release/Plus-and-Cummins-Collaborate-to-Develop-the-Industry-First-Supervised-Autonomous-Trucks-Using-a-Natural-Gas-Powertrain.html\">working with Cummins </a>to create autonomous technology for natural gas trucks.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
